{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Corey Lewandowski |image=Corey Lewandowski 2017-08-03.jpg |caption= Lewandowski in 2017 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|9|18}} |birth_place = [[Lowell, Massachusetts]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = {{marriage|Alison Hardy|2005}} |children = 4 |education = [[University of Massachusetts Lowell|University of Massachusetts,
Lowell]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[American University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]]) }} '''Corey R. Lewandowski''' ({{IPAc-en|l|ɛ|v|æ|n|d|ʊ|v|s|k|i}}; born September 18, 1973){{cite news |last1=Stokols |first1=Eli |last2=Gold |first2=Hadas |last3=Gass |first3=Nick |title=Trump turns blame on reporter in battery case |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/03/trump-campaign-manager-charged-with-misdemeanor-battery-221336 |accessdate=April 10, 2016 |publisher=Politico |date=March 29, 2016 |archivedate=April 9, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160409071126/http://www.politico.com/story/2016/03/trump-campaign-manager-charged-with-misdemeanor-battery-221336 |deadurl=no |quote=The police report states, 'Based on the above-described investigation, probable cause exists to charge Corey Lewandowski DOB 9/18/1973...'}} is an American [[political campaign staff|political operative]], [[Lobbying|lobbyist]] and [[Pundit|political commentator]]. He was a political commentator for [[One America News Network]] (OANN), [[Fox News]] and [[CNN]], as well as a [[campaign manager]] of [[Donald Trump]]'s 2016 [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|campaign for President of the United States]] from January 2015 to June 2016. Prior to joining Trump's campaign, Lewandowski worked on several campaigns, worked for the conservative [[advocacy group]] [[Americans for Prosperity]] and was a [[lobbying|lobbyist]]. Lewandowski himself has run unsuccessfully for office twice, once in Massachusetts and once in New Hampshire. On December 21, 2016, Lewandowski co-founded Avenue Strategies, a lobbying firm in an office overlooking the White House. He left the firm in May 2017. ==Early life and education== Lewandowski was raised in [[Lowell, Massachusetts]].{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/07/man-behind-donald-trump-run-lewandowski-120443.html|title=The man behind Donald Trump's run|last1=Schreckinger|first1=Ben|date=July 22, 2015|work=Politico|accessdate=July 23, 2015|last2=Martel|first2=Cate}} One of his grandfathers was a printer. He is of Polish and French-Canadian descent.{{cite web| url= http://www.polskatimes.pl/fakty/swiat/a/corey-lewandowski-doradca-o-polskich-korzeniach-prowadzi-donalda-trumpa-na-szczyty,9453463/ | title= Corey Lewandowski - doradca o polskich korzeniach prowadzi Donalda Trumpa na szczyty | website= Polskatimes.pl | language= Polish}}{{cite web |url=https://b.3cdn.net/uchicago/41bb73da6033834bd1_bsm6ib0nu.pdf |title=The Axe Files |date=February 20, 2017 |website=b.3cdn.net|format=PDF}} Lewandowski graduated in 1991 from [[Lowell Catholic High School]], a private, not-for-profit, [[college-preparatory school]] in Lowell.{{cite web |url=http://www.lowellsun.com/news/ci_28532424/stump-trump-lowell-native-corey-lewandowski-running-presidential |title= On the stump for Trump: Lowell native Corey Lewandowski running presidential campaign |date=July 24, 2015 |work=[[The Sun (Lowell)|The Lowell Sun]] |accessdate= March 14, 2016}} In 1995, he graduated from the [[University of Massachusetts at Lowell]] with a B.A. in political science.{{cite web |first1=Matt |last1=Stout |url=https://www.uml.edu/News/news-articles/2015/herald-trump-manager.aspx |title=Trumpeting The Donald |newspaper= Boston Herald |date=July 25, 2015}} He received a [[master's degree]] in [[political science]] from [[American University]] in Washington, DC, in 1997. ==Political career== ===1994 State House campaign=== [[File:Corey Lewandowski (28815701733).jpg|thumb|right|Lewandowski during his 1994 campaign]] In 1994, while an undergraduate student, Lewandowski ran for a seat in the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives]] as a [[write-in candidate]] in the Republican primary. He received 143 votes, falling short of the 150 votes needed to win the party's nomination for the ballot. In the November general election, the seat was won by [[Thomas A. Golden Jr.]], a Democrat.{{cite web |first=Jon |last=Swaine |date=April 1, 2016 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/apr/01/corey-lewandowski-massachusetts-state-election |title=Trump campaign manager sued to get on Massachusetts ballot as 21-year-old |newspaper=The Guardian}} Golden received 7,157 votes, while Lewandowski received 7 votes."[http://electionstats.state.ma.us/elections/view/6501/ 1994 State Representative General Election: 15th Middlesex District]". ''Massachusetts Election Statistics''. Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Accessed on June 27, 2016. ===Early work=== After graduating from college, Lewandowski worked as an aide for Republican [[Massachusetts's 6th congressional district|Massachusetts Congressman]] [[Peter G. Torkildsen]]"[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=0EB54920B99184CA&p_docnum=2&p_queryname=5 Out With Old, In With New]". ''Associated Press''. Tulsa World. November 23, 1996. from January 1996 to January 1997, while a graduate student at [[American University]]. Also while a student in 1997, Lewandowski interned for Massachusetts State Senator [[Steven C. Panagiotakos]], a Democrat. From December 1997 to February 2001, Lewandowski worked as an administrative assistant for Ohio Republican [[Bob Ney]], a U.S. Congressman. In 2007, before Ney was [[Sentence (law)|sentenced]] on federal corruption charges arising from the [[Jack Abramoff Indian lobbying scandal|Abramoff lobbying scandal]], Lewandowski wrote a letter to the presiding judge, saying that Ney was a mentor and "surrogate father" to him and asking for leniency in sentencing.{{cite web |first=Will |last=Rahn |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/08/03/donald-trump-s-campaign-chief-backed-a-crooked-congressman-called-him-my-surrogate-father.html |title=Donald Trump's Campaign Chief Backed a Crooked Congressman, Called Him 'My Surrogate Father' |work=The Daily Beast |date=August 3, 2015}}{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Rogers |url=https://www.npr.org/2016/02/22/467499682/meet-donald-trumps-alter-ego |title=Meet Donald Trump's Alter Ego |publisher=All Things Considered |agency=NPR |date=February 22, 2016}} In 1999, while working for Ney, Lewandowski brought a loaded handgun in a laundry bag into the [[Longworth House Office Building]].{{cite news |last=Tumulty |first=Karen |authorlink=Karen Tumulty |date=March 30, 2016 |title=Who is Corey Lewandowski? His rise — and his relationship with Donald Trump |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-and-lewandowski-an-unlikely-pair-of-kindred-spirits/2016/03/30/d82a58ca-f511-11e5-8b23-538270a1ca31_story.html |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=March 30, 2016}}DiStaso, John. "[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=0F544F6C0C135F47&p_docnum=10&p_queryname=2 GOP chairman explains the ground rules]". ''The New Hampshire Union Leader''. December 20, 2001. He was arrested and charged with a [[misdemeanor]]. Lewandowski said it was an accident, that he forgot the gun was in the bag when he put the laundry in it. The charges eventually were dismissed; Lewandowski then unsuccessfully fought for four years to get the gun back, filing lawsuits in multiple District of Columbia and federal courts.{{Cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/03/31/supreme-court-merrick-garland-trump-lewandowski-arrest-gun/82475010/ |title=Merrick Garland heard Trump campaign manager’s appeal over gun in 2003 |last=Wolf |first=Richard |date=March 31, 2016 |website=USA TODAY|access-date=June 20, 2016}} After leaving Ney's office, Lewandowski worked most of 2001 for the [[Republican National Committee]] as the Northeast legislative political director. ===Smith campaign=== Lewandowski was the [[campaign manager]] for the [[United States Senate election in New Hampshire, 2002|2002 re-election campaign]] of [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Robert C. Smith]] of New Hampshire.DiStaso, John. "[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=0F544F68E88BEC97&p_docnum=6&p_queryname=5 Will Stickney back Sununu? Not in the cards]". ''New Hampshire Union Leader''. November 29, 2001. Smith was challenged in the Republican primary by [[John E. Sununu]]. Speaking about Sununu, Lewandowski said, "The people of New Hampshire want someone in the U.S. Senate with clear, concise views on terrorism. They'll judge a congressman based on the people he associates with, his voting record and his campaign contributions."Babington, Charles. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/2001/12/23/smith-takes-swipe-at-sununu-white-house-swipes-back/55cd43f2-c6a0-4cc0-b3ff-fe721ffd95d6/ Smith Takes Swipe at Sununu, White House Swipes Back]". ''The Washington Post'' (December 23, 2001). Lewandowski told a reporter he would be interested to know whether anyone associated with [[Hamas]] had attended a fundraising event for Sununu.Fahey, Tom. "[http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=0F544F6B5279E742&p_docnum=8&p_queryname=2 White House gets involved in Smith-Sununu election discord]". ''The New Hampshire Union Leader''. December 15, 2001. (Lewandowski cited contributions made by Washington lawyer George Salem to Sununu; Salem, who chaired Arab Americans for Bush-Cheney during the [[George W. Bush presidential campaign, 2000|2000 Bush/Cheney campaign]], was the attorney for the [[Holy Land Foundation for Relief and Development]], which had its assets frozen by the U.S. government in 2001 on suspicion of ties to Hamas.) Lewandowski's comments were interpreted as publicly suggesting that Sununu, who is of [[Lebanese American|Lebanese descent]], had divided loyalties in fighting terrorism. Former [[Governor of New Hampshire|New Hampshire Governor]] [[Steve Merrill]] said, "The politics of ethnic slurs and bigotry have no place in any campaign." Former [[List of United States Senators from New Hampshire|New Hampshire Senator]] [[Warren Rudman]] said, "Bob Smith is a better human being than that, and he ought to tell his people to watch themselves." [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]]'s spokesperson said, "The White House called Senator Smith's office ... Remarks that paint [[Arab Americans]] with a broad brush aren't helpful. We need to reassure Arab Americans that this war is about al-Qaida, not Islam. Mr. Salem is a good friend of the president's and an honorable man." Smith's press secretary said Lewandowski was "merely responding to media inquiries" about Salem's fund raising and that "Senator Smith has repeatedly said this campaign is about records—Congressman Sununu's record and Senator Smith's record. Someone's ethnic background has absolutely nothing to do with this election." Sununu defeated Smith in the Republican primary, winning 53% of the vote to Smith's 45%."[http://www.fec.gov/pubrec/fe2002/senate.htm Federal Elections 2002 U.S. Senate Results]". ''Federal Election Commission''. 2002.{{cite web |first=Maggie |last=Haberman |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/04/us/politics/donald-trump-corey-lewandowski-campaign-manager.html |title=For His Unconventional Campaign, Donald Trump Looks to an Unorthodox Manager |work=The New York Times |date=September 4, 2015}} Smith was the first sitting U.S. senator in ten years to lose a primary campaign. ===Schwartz MSL, Americans for Prosperity, and other work=== From 2003 to 2004, Lewandowski was executive director of the New England Seafood Producers Association.{{cite news |title=Can Corey Lewandowski save New England's seafood industry? |date=July 16, 2003 |url=http://www.intrafish.com/news/article1313282.ece |magazine=Intrafish}}{{cite web |first=Jason |last=Dick |url=http://www.sunherald.com/news/politics-government/article69028562.html |title=Who Is Corey Lewandowski? Trump campaign manager, seasoned political operative |work=CQ-Roll Call |date=March 30, 2016}} From 2004 to 2012, Lewandowski worked for [[Schwartz Communications|Schwartz MSL]], a strategic communication and engagement firm where, according to his [[LinkedIn]] profile, he served as director of public affairs from September 2004 until July 2012. Lewandowski was registered as a lobbyist for Schwartz MSL on behalf of Passport Systems in 2011, lobbying on homeland security issues. Schwartz represented Passport Systems for six years, and the firm paid Schwartz more than $350,000 over that period. Between 2008 and 2011, Passport Systems secured more than $23.9 million in federal funds. Lewandowski represented two other clients: health care software company Logical Images and solar-power company Borrego Solar.{{cite web |first=Russ |last=Choma |url=http://www.newsweek.com/corey-lewandowski-donald-trump-solar-power-442314 |title=Donald Trump Campaign Manager's Diametric Double Life as a Solar Power Lobbyist |work=Newsweek |date=March 30, 2016}} Lewandowski graduated from the New Hampshire police academy in 2006 and worked from 2006 to 2010 as a [[Seasonal industry|seasonal]] marine patrol officer trainee with the [[New Hampshire State Police]].{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/03/donald-trump-corey-lewandowski-220742 |title=Trump campaign manager's behavior prompted staff concerns |last2=Schreckinger |first2=Ben |date=March 15, 2016 |last3=Gold |first3=Hadas |last1=Vogel |first1=Kenneth |work=Politico |accessdate=March 30, 2016}}{{cite web |last1=Stevenson |first1=Seth |title=A Week on the Trail With the "Disgusting Reporters" Covering Donald Trump |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/cover_story/2016/03/on_the_trail_with_donald_trump_s_disgusting_press_corps.html |website=Slate |accessdate=March 30, 2016}} In 2008, Lewandowski began working for [[Americans for Prosperity]], a [[Political activities of the Koch brothers|Koch brothers]]-backed advocacy group. Lewandowski's period working for Americans for Prosperity overlapped with his tenure as a marine patrol officer trainee and registered federal lobbyist. Lewandowski was Americans for Prosperity's New Hampshire director,{{cite news |title=How to Live Freer in New Hampshire |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=February 25, 2011 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/853948353/CC39FFE005574B6APQ/6?accountid=46320}} and East Coast regional director before becoming the national director of voter registration, a position he held until January 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/2016-elections/donald-trump-is-buying-a-new-hampshire-campaign-wholesale-20150707|title=Donald Trump Is Buying a New Hampshire Campaign Wholesale|last=Dáte|first=S. V.|date=July 7, 2015|work=National Journal|accessdate=July 23, 2015}} Lewandowski's term at Americans for Prosperity was described by ''[[Politico]]'' as "tumultuous" and marked by "fiery confrontations" with other AFP employees. While working for Americans for Prosperity, Lewandowski criticized the [[Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative]], a [[cap-and-trade]] system for state utilities, saying "it does nothing to reduce greenhouse gases because jobs and businesses just move to other states." At the same time, Lewandowski lobbied for Borrego Solar, helping to secure a $500,000 [[Earmark (politics)|earmark]] in the 2010 Energy and Water Appropriations Act that benefited a solar electricity project in [[Lancaster, Massachusetts]], that Borrego was involved in. ''Newsweek'' noted, "though he had succeeded as a pro-solar lobbyist looking for government assistance, at AFP he waged a campaign against government programs that supported [[green energy]]." In 2012, while still working for Americans for Prosperity, Lewandowski unsuccessfully ran for town treasurer of [[Windham, New Hampshire]]. NPR reported that during the campaign, Lewandowski "upended the town's politics, using public records laws to probe local government and launching [[robocall]]s targeted at voters to stoke outrage over a visit to the town by President Obama." Robert Skinner defeated Lewandowski, receiving 1,941 votes to Lewandowski's 714."[http://www.eagletribune.com/community/windham-town-results/article_d25052c6-a08d-5b95-97ec-985ad3e50040.html Windham Town Results]". ''Eagle-Tribune'' (North Andover, Massachusetts). March 5, 2012. ==Trump 2016 presidential campaign== Lewandowski first met Trump in April 2014 at a political event in New Hampshire.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/wp/2015/07/23/meet-the-man-behind-donald-trumps-presidential-campaign/|title=Meet the man behind Donald Trump’s presidential campaign|last=Phillips|first=Amber|date=July 23, 2015|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=July 23, 2015}} In January 2015, six months before Trump announced his campaign, Lewandowski was invited to [[Trump Tower]], where he accepted an offer from Trump to become campaign manager. His salary was $20,000 per month.{{Cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-spends-big-on-campaign-and-salaries-1437067020 |title=One Sign of Inflation: Salaries for Some Presidential Campaigns |last=Ballhaus |first=Rebecca |date=July 17, 2015 |last2=Haddon |first2=Heather |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |issn=0099-9660|access-date=June 20, 2016}} When Lewandowski was hired, Trump's political staff consisted of three people: his lawyer [[Michael D. Cohen (lawyer)|Michael D. Cohen]], veteran operative [[Roger Stone]], and aide [[Sam Nunberg]].{{Cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2015/08/trump-campaign-has-descended-into-civil-war.html |title=The Trump Campaign Has Descended Into Civil War - Even Ivanka Has Gotten Involved |last=Sherman |first=Gabriel |date=August 6, 2015 |magazine=New York|access-date=June 20, 2016}} In April 2016, another veteran GOP operative, [[Paul Manafort]], was hired; the following month Manafort was named “campaign chairman.”{{Cite web |url=http://talkingpointsmemo.com/news/how-did-corey-lewandowski-last-so-long |title=How Did Corey Lewandowski Last This Long? |last=Kirkland |first=Allegra |date=June 20, 2016 |website=TPM|access-date=June 20, 2016}} Nunberg was fired in early August 2015;{{Cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/31/politics/trump-adviser-sam-nunberg-facebook-posts/index.html |title=Trump campaign fires staffer over Facebook posts |last=Diamond |first=Jeremy |website=CNN|access-date=June 20, 2016}} he believes that it was Lewandowski and campaign press secretary [[Hope Hicks]] who asked Trump for his ouster.{{Cite web |url=https://www.gq.com/story/hope-hicks-mystifying-triumph-donald-trump |title=The Mystifying Triumph of Hope Hicks, Donald Trump's Right-Hand Woman |last=Nuzzi |first=Olivia |date=June 20, 2016 |website=GQ|access-date=June 21, 2016}} Stone left the campaign a week later.{{Cite web |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/08/sources-roger-stone-quit-wasnt-fired-by-donald-trump-in-campaign-shakeup-121177 |title=Sources: Roger Stone quit, wasn't fired by Trump in campaign shakeup |last=Caputo |first=Marc |date=August 8, 2015 |website=Politico|access-date=June 20, 2016}} Lewandowski's motto as Trump's campaign manager was "Let Trump be Trump"; those words appeared on his office white board.{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/meet-the-man-who-helps-trump-be-trump-1455153779 |title=Meet the Man Who Helps Trump Be Trump |date=February 10, 2016 |work=Wall Street Journal}} Trump said of Lewandowski, "He leaves me alone, but he knows when to make his presence felt." Lewandowski was identified in the [[George Papadopoulos]] court documents as the "High-Ranking Campaign Official".{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/whos-who-in-the-george-papadopoulos-court-documents/2017/10/30/e131158c-bdb3-11e7-97d9-bdab5a0ab381_story.html |title=Who’s who in the George Papadopoulos court documents |first1=Rosalind S. |last1=Helderman |date=November 2, 2017 |website=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=November 2, 2017 |quote=“High-Ranking Campaign Official”: Campaign manager Corey Lewandowski.}} After a win in New Hampshire on February 9, 2016, Trump acknowledged Lewandowski's role in the win by praising his ground game. === Physical incidents === [[File:Trump rally police video.jpg|thumb|right|Capture from a police video showing Lewandowski, while working as Donald Trump's campaign manager, grabbing the arm of Michelle Fields, a former Breitbart reporter.]] On March 10, 2016, [[Michelle Fields]], a reporter for [[Breitbart News]], wrote that, after she asked [[Donald Trump]] a question when she approached him after a March 8, 2016, press conference in [[Jupiter, Florida]], she was forcefully grabbed by Lewandowski.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/inside-trumps-inner-circle-his-staffers-are-willing-to-fight-for-him-literally/2016/03/10/4b2b18e8-e660-11e5-a6f3-21ccdbc5f74e_story.html |title=Inside Trump's inner circle, his staffers are willing to fight for him. Literally. |work=The Washington Post |date=March 10, 2016 |accessdate=March 12, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/03/11/video-shows-trump-campaign-manager-corey-lewandowski-grabbing-reporter-michelle-fields.html |title=Video Shows Trump Campaign Manager Corey Lewandowski Grabbing Reporter Michelle Fields |work=The Daily Beast |date=March 11, 2016 |accessdate=March 12, 2016}} On March 29, Lewandowski was charged with one count of [[simple battery]] by the Jupiter Police Department and surrendered himself to the authorities, after releasing a statement maintaining his innocence.{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/03/29/trump-campaign-manager-corey-lewandowski-charged-with-battery-for-grabbing-reporter-in-florida.html |title=Trump campaign manager Lewandowski charged with battery |work=CNBC |date=March 29, 2016 |accessdate=March 29, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/local/trump-aide-charged-with-misdemeanor-battery-on-ex-/nqtkY/ |title=Trump aide charged with misdemeanor battery vs. ex-Breitbart reporter |work=Palm Beach Post |date=March 29, 2016 |accessdate=March 29, 2016}}{{cite news |title=Busted! Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski officially charged with assaulting ex-Breitbart staffer |url=http://www.salon.com/2016/03/29/busted_trump_campaign_manger_corey_lewandowski_officially_charged_with_assaulting_ex_breitbart_staffer/ |work=Salon |first=Sophia |last=Tesfaye |date=March 29, 2016 |accessdate=March 29, 2016}} Two weeks later, [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach County]] [[State Attorney]] [[Dave Aronberg]] said that his office would not prosecute Lewandowski; they believed that "there was [[probable cause]] to make an arrest" and "the facts support the allegation that Mr. Lewandowski did grab Ms. Fields' arm against her will," but "the evidence cannot prove all legally required [[Element (criminal law)|elements of the crime]] alleged and is insufficient to support a criminal prosecution."{{cite news |first=Curt |last=Anderson |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_GOP_2016_TRUMP_CAMPAIGN_MANAGER?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2016-04-14-13-46-32 |title=Prosecutor won't pursue battery charge against Trump aide |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=April 14, 2015 |accessdate=April 14, 2016 |archivedate=April 14, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6gljGiEDo?url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_GOP_2016_TRUMP_CAMPAIGN_MANAGER?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2016-04-14-13-46-32 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all}} On March 19, 2016, during a campaign event in [[Tucson, Arizona]], Lewandowski drew criticism for his handling of a protester. |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/03/20/donald-trump-faults-protesters-over-violence-not-their-assailants/ |title=Trump faults protesters over violence, 2016 |publisher=ABC News |accessdate=March 21, 2016}} === Departure === In April 2016, Lewandowski's influence within the Trump campaign was reported to be waning.{{cite news |first1=Ben |last1=Schreckinger |first2=Kenneth P. |last2=Vogel |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/donald-trump-corey-lewandowski-shrinking-role-campaign-221487 |title=Trump campaign shrinks Lewandowski's |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/apr/14/trump-campaign-manager-corey-lewandowski-battery-charges |title=Trump's campaign manager Corey Lewandowski will not face battery charges |newspaper=The Guardian |date=April 14, 2016 |accessdate=April 14, 2016 |quote=While Trump has stood by Lewandowski through the controversy, the political operative's influence has been waning in recent weeks. This has not been connected to allegations of violence but instead to internal maneuverings as the Trump campaign tries to build an operation, led by veteran Republican operative Paul Manafort, capable of wooing delegates in a contested convention.}} On June 20, 2016, Trump's campaign announced that it was parting ways with Lewandowski; according to reports, Lewandowski was fired, although [[Donald Trump Jr.]], Trump's son, described the split as "amicable."{{cite news |first1=Maggie |last1=Haberman |authorlink=Maggie Haberman |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/21/us/politics/corey-lewandowski-donald-trump.html |title=Donald Trump Fires Corey Lewandowski, His Campaign Manager |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 20, 2016 |accessdate=June 20, 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/06/20/trump-splits-with-campaign-manager-lewandowski.html |title=Trump splits with campaign manager Lewandowski |publisher=Fox News |date=June 20, 2016 |accessdate=June 20, 2016}} The move occurred after Lewandowski clashed with Trump chief strategist and campaign chairman [[Paul Manafort]] in an internal "power struggle." After Lewandowski's departure, Manafort (who had been brought on the campaign in March 2016) became the ''[[de facto]]'' campaign manager.{{cite news |first1=Jonathan |last1=Martin |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/19/us/politics/john-kasich-rnc.html |title=Trump Campaign Denounces John Kasich in Ohio, Where Convention Begins |newspaper=The New York Times |date=July 18, 2016 |accessdate=July 20, 2016}} ==Political commentator and lobbyist== ===CNN=== Days after Lewandowski left the Trump campaign, he was hired by the cable news network [[CNN]] as a political commentator.{{Cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/06/23/media/corey-lewandowski-cnn/ |title=CNN hires Corey Lewandowski as political commentator |publisher=[[CNN]] |first=Brian |last=Stelter |date=June 23, 2016 |accessdate=June 30, 2016 |archivedate=June 24, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624113831/http://money.cnn.com/2016/06/23/media/corey-lewandowski-cnn/ |deadurl=no}} Lewandowski remains subject to a [[non-disclosure agreement]] that he signed with Trump, forbidding him "from making disparaging or revealing remarks about the candidate."{{cite news |first1=Nick |last1=Corasaniti |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/04/us/politics/corey-lewandowski-obama-birther.html |title=Corey Lewandowski, Former Trump Campaign Manager, Dives Back Into 'Birtherism' |newspaper=The New York Times |date=August 3, 2016 |accessdate=August 4, 2016}} Lewandowski received [[severance pay]] from the Trump campaign while working for CNN. In July 2016, after the group [[Media Matters for America]] noted that CNN had not disclosed this to viewers, CNN hosts began making on-air disclosures of the severance payments before Lewandowski's appearances.{{cite news |first1=David |last1=Bauder |url=http://www.wthr.com/article/cnn-revealing-lewandowskis-severance-payments |title=CNN revealing Lewandowski's severance payments |agency=Associated Press |date=July 13, 2016 |accessdate=July 14, 2016}} In July 2016, Lewandowski defended Trump who had been criticized after [[Twitter|tweeting]] a graphic that labeled [[Hillary Clinton]] the "most corrupt candidate" alongside a pile of cash and a six-pointed star evoking the [[Star of David]]. (The image originated on an Internet message board featuring [[Antisemitic canard|antisemitic conspiracy theories]]). During an appearance on CNN's ''[[State of the Union (TV series)|State of the Union]]'' with [[Brianna Keilar]], Lewandowski denied allegations of [[antisemitism]] and said that criticism of the tweet was "[[political correctness]] run amok."{{cite news |first1=Jeremy |last1=Diamond |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/02/politics/donald-trump-tweet-graphic-star-hillary-clinton/ |title=Trump campaign defends tweet as a 'basic star' in wake of criticism |publisher=CNN |date=July 4, 2016}}{{cite web |last1=Robillard |first1=Kevin |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/corey-lewandowski-star-david-donald-trump-225072 |title=Lewandowski blames Star of David blowup on 'political correctness' |work=Politico |accessdate=July 4, 2016 |date=July 3, 2016}} In an August 2016 appearance on CNN, Lewandowski espoused the [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|"birther" conspiracy theory]], suggesting that President [[Barack Obama]] was not a [[Natural-born-citizen clause|natural-born-citizen]] of the United States.{{cite news |first1=Nick |last1=Gass |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/obama-birther-corey-lewandowski-226607 |title=CNN contributor Corey Lewandowski: Was Obama a citizen when he went to Harvard? |work=Politico |date=August 3, 2016 |accessdate=August 4, 2016}} Lewandowski's statement was criticized by the other panelists, Angela Rye and [[Bakari Sellers]]. On November 11, 2016, Lewandowski resigned as a CNN commentator amid speculations that he would play a role in the [[Trump administration]].{{cite news |first1=Brian |last1=Stelter |url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/11/11/media/corey-lewandowski-resigns-cnn/ |title=Corey Lewandowski resigns from CNN |work=CNNMoney |date=November 11, 2016 |accessdate=November 12, 2016}} ===OANN=== After leaving CNN, Lewandowski worked as a political commentator for the cable news television channel [[One America News Network]] (OANN).{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/on-media/2017/01/corey-lewandowski-joins-conservative-news-network-as-commentator-233559|title=Corey Lewandowski joins conservative news channel OANN as commentator|last=Sutton|first=Kelsey|date=January 12, 2017|accessdate=July 12, 2017|publisher=''[[Politico]]''}} While he mainly worked for OANN, he made sporadic appearances on [[Fox News]]. Lewandowski was fired from OANN on July 31, 2017, for appearing on news networks outside of OANN.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/media/344719-lewandowski-fired-from-pro-trump-cable-network-report|title=Lewandowski fired from pro-Trump cable network: report|last=Master|first=Cyra|date=July 31, 2017|accessdate=August 1, 2017|publisher=''The Hill''}}{{cite news |publisher=''[[The Daily Beast]]'' |title=Corey Lewandowski Fired From One America News Network |first=Lachlan |last=Markay |first2=Asawin |last2=Suebsaeng |date=July 31, 2017 |access-date=August 1, 2017 |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/corey-lewandowski-has-been-fired-from-the-one-america-news-network}} ===Avenue Strategies=== On December 21, 2016, Lewandowski and Barry Bennett, a "former Trump senior adviser", whom Lewandowski had known for ten years,{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/13/opinion/want-to-keep-the-president-at-bay-two-consultants-have-an-inside-track.html |title=Want to Keep the President at Bay? Two Consultants Have an Inside Track |first=Elizabeth |last=Williams |date=March 13, 2017 |accessdate=May 12, 2017 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}} co-founded as equal partners a political consulting firm called Avenue Strategies. They were joined by other Trump presidential campaign veterans. Bennett, Mike Rubino, Jason Osborne, and most of Lewandowski's associates at Avenue Strategies filed lobbying registrations. Mainly because of Lewandowski, Avenue Strategies soon became one of "the highest-profile government-affairs outfits in Washington". Avenue Strategies' office "overlooks the White House", and Lewandowski has "relatively unimpeded access" to President Trump either by phone or in person at the White House. Access to President Trump can be "highly lucrative" — "relatively few established K Street powerhouses have ties to the new president". In February 2017, Avenue Strategies "quietly agreed" to lobby for [[Citgo|Citgo Petroleum Corporation]] (Citgo). In April they signed a $25,000 a month contract as tensions mounted between the United States, Venezuela, and Russia.{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/05/03/corey-lewandowski-citgo-deal-237960 |work=Politico |date=May 3, 2017 |accessdate=May 12, 2017 |first1=Kenneth P. |last1=Vogel |title=Lewandowski’s firm quietly inked deal with Venezuela-owned company: Contract to lobby for Citgo comes amid rising tensions}} Citgo is headquartered in Houston, Texas, but is owned by the government of Venezuela. Citgo took out a loan from Russian state-owned oil giant, [[Rosneft]] in December 2016 that it has been unable to pay. It is under threat of a takeover by Rosneft. By early May the legally required paperwork had not been filed revealing the contract to the U.S. Government through the Senate Office of Public Records. The governor of debt-ridden Puerto Rico hired Avenue Strategies to lobby Congress for funding. Avenue Strategies also "operates a fledgling super PAC to help Trump win re-election". According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', the firm's corporate clients — [[Fortune 100]] companies — hire them as insurance against "tweet risk". Bennett said, "If he’s gonna come after you, there’s nothing we can do to stop it. But if you want to figure out how to win in this environment, we can help you. [For example], [c]all [[Jared Kushner]] and tell him you’re gonna build a new factory," or invite Mr. Trump to "fly somewhere, cut a ribbon, and high-five 200 employees... [That] "drives optimism, and it drives his power. There are few things a president can do to build power faster than to lead a great economic comeback." Lewandowski added, "We’re your sherpa through turbulent times." While at the firm, Lewandowski won a $160,000 account with Community Choice Financial, a large [[payday lender]].{{cite news |last1=Confessore |first1=Nicholas |authorlink1=Nicholas Confessore |last2=Vogel |first2=Kenneth P. |title=Trump Loyalist Mixes Businesses and Access at ‘Advisory’ Firm |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/01/us/politics/corey-lewandowski-trump.html |accessdate=August 3, 2017 |work=The New York Times |date=August 2, 2017 |page=A1}} Lewandowski did not formally register as a lobbyist as he did not consider himself to be a lobbyist.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-05-04/lewandowski-breaks-with-partner-amid-reports-of-foreign-clients |title=Lewandowski Exits Lobby Firm Amid Reports of Foreign Clients |first1=Jennifer |last1=Jacobs |first2=Ben |last2=Brody |date=May 4, 2017 |accessdate=May 12, 2017 |work=Bloomberg}} However, he was criticized by "competing lobbyists and ethics watchdogs" for "flouting the spirit of the lobbying rules, and abusing his access to the Trump White House". On May 3, 2017, [[Public Citizen]], a "government-ethics group, asked the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]] to investigate whether Lewandowski should have registered as a foreign or domestic lobbyist". On May 4, 2017, Lewandowski left Avenue Strategies. ====Washington East West Political Strategies==== In an article published on April 28, 2017 ''POLITICO'' revealed that they had obtained documents about Washington East West Political Strategies — an "affiliate of Avenue Strategies". It was one of "several international recruitment vehicles" through which business partners globally — including those in the Middle East, Canada, and Central America — could "earn commissions by enlisting international clients" for Avenue Strategies. East West solicited "business in Eastern Europe and elsewhere by offering access to Trump, Vice President Mike Pence and other top administration officials".{{cite news |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/28/corey-lewandowski-trump-meetings-237725 |work=Politico |date=April 28, 2017 |accessdate=May 12, 2017 |first1=Kenneth P. |last1=Vogel |first2=Josh |last2=Dawsey |title=Lewandowski’s firm appears to offer Trump meetings: Ex-campaign manager says he’s not a lobbyist, but documents suggest his firm has been offering to secure face time with the president for foreign politicians.}} ___?___ that described "numerous proposed activities that would seem to trigger [[Foreign Agents Registration Act]] (FARA) registration". East West was created by Lewandowski, Bennett, Rauf Mammadov, "an Azerbaijani oil executive and an American political consultant who works extensively in Russia", Marshall Comins, who "worked extensively in the former Soviet Union and Sub-Saharan Africa consulting governments, high net-worth individuals and politicians", Jeff Monson, a "prominent figure in Russia’s Communist Party", and Mike Nicholas Sango, "Zimbabwe's ambassador to Russia." On May 3 Avenue Strategies dissolved East West with Bennett and Lewandowski both claiming that their collaborators, Mammadov and Comins, had issued the East West document, not them. Bennett explained that "Avenue Strategies owned the equity — and that is me and Corey — but he didn’t have any role....[I]t is a "violation of our understanding with them." Lewandowski said he had "no affiliation or involvement" and "never entered into any agreement with [East West]." ===Lewandowski Strategic Advisors=== On May 12, 2017, eight days after leaving Avenue Strategies, Lewandowski incorporated Lewandowski Strategic Advisors in Delaware, which, as an advisory firm, does not register as a lobbyist or disclose its clients. Sprague de Camp|Divide and Rule (collection)}} {{distinguish|divide and choose}} {{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=November 2007}} {{original research|date=August 2007}} {{globalize|date=November 2011}} }}
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Philip-ii-of-macedon.jpg|thumb|right|Tradition attributes the origin of the motto to [[Philip of Macedonia]]: διαίρει καὶ βασίλευε ''diaírei kài basíleue'', in [[Ancient Greek language|ancient Greek]]: «divide and rule»]] '''Divide and rule''' (from [[Latin]] ''dīvide et imperā''), or '''divide and conquer''', in [[politics]] and [[sociology]] is gaining and maintaining [[Power (social and political)|power]] by breaking up larger concentrations of power into pieces that individually have less power than the one implementing the strategy. The concept refers to a strategy that breaks up existing power structures, and especially prevents smaller power groups from linking up, causing rivalries and fomenting discord among the people. It was heavily used by [[British Empire]] in [[India]] and elsewhere.<ref name="Ilia Xypolia 2016. P. 9">Ilia Xypolia. 'Divide et Impera: Vertical and Horizontal Dimensions of British Imperialism'. Critique: journal of socialist theory, vol 44, no. 3, pp. 221-231, 2016. P. 221.</ref>
[[Traiano Boccalini]] cites "divide et impera" in ''La bilancia politica''<ref>'''1''' §136 and '''2''' §225</ref> as a common principle in politics. The use of this technique is meant to empower the sovereign to control subjects, populations, or factions of different interests, who collectively might be able to oppose his rule. [[Machiavelli]] identifies a similar application to military strategy, advising in Book VI of ''The Art of War''<ref>[http://etext.library.adelaide.edu.au/m/machiavelli/niccolo/m149a/chapter6.html http://etext.library.adelaide.edu.au] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070625213056/http://etext.library.adelaide.edu.au/m/machiavelli/niccolo/m149a/chapter6.html |date=25 June 2007 }}</ref> (''Dell'arte della guerra''),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intratext.com/IXT/ITA1109/_P7.HTM|title=Dell'arte della guerra: testo - IntraText CT|work=intratext.com}}</ref> that a Captain should endeavor with every art to divide the forces of the enemy, either by making him suspicious of his men in whom he trusted, or by giving him cause that he has to separate his forces, and, because of this, become weaker.
The maxim ''divide et impera'' has been attributed to [[Philip II of Macedon]], and together with the maxim ''divide ut regnes'' was utilised by the Roman ruler [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]] and the French emperor [[Napoleon]].
The strategy, but not the phrase, applies in many ancient cases: the example of [[Aulus Gabinius|Gabinius]] exists, parting [[Iudaea Province|the Jewish nation]] into five conventions, reported by [[Flavius Josephus]] in Book I, 169-170 of ''The Wars of the Jews'' (''De bello Judaico'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=J.+BJ+1.159 |title=Flavius Josephus, The Wars of the Jews, Book I, section 159 |publisher=[[Perseus Project]] |date= |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref> [[Strabo]] also reports in ''Geography'', 8.7.3<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Strab.+8.7.1 |title=Strabo, Geography, Book 8, chapter 7, section 1 |publisher=[[Perseus Project]] |date= |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref> that the [[Achaean League]] was gradually dissolved under the Roman possession of the whole of [[Macedonia (ancient kingdom)|Macedonia]], owing to them not dealing with the several states in the same way, but wishing to preserve some and to destroy others.
The strategy of division and rule has been attributed to sovereigns, ranging from [[Louis XI]] to [[Habsburgs|the Habsburgs]]. [[Edward Coke]] denounces it in Chapter I of the Fourth Part of the ''Institutes'', reporting that when it was demanded by the [[House of Lords|Lords]] and [[British House of Commons|Commons]] what might be a principal motive for them to have good success in [[Parliament of England|Parliament]], it was answered: "''Eritis insuperabiles, si fueritis inseparabiles. Explosum est illud diverbium: Divide, & impera, cum radix & vertex imperii in obedientium consensu rata sunt.''" [You would be insuperable if you were inseparable. This proverb, Divide and rule, has been rejected, since the root and the summit of authority are confirmed by the consent of the subjects.] On the other hand, in a minor variation, [[Francis Bacon|Sir Francis Bacon]] wrote the phrase "separa et impera" in a letter to [[James I of England|James I]] of 15 February 1615. [[James Madison]] made this recommendation in a letter to [[Thomas Jefferson]] of 24 October 1787,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press-pubs.uchicago.edu/founders/documents/v1ch17s22.html |title=Constitutional Government: James Madison to Thomas Jefferson |publisher=Press-pubs.uchicago.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref> which summarized the thesis of ''[[Federalist Papers|The Federalist#10]]'':<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.constitution.org/fed/federa10.htm|title=The Federalist #10|work=constitution.org}}</ref> "Divide et impera, the reprobated axiom of tyranny, is under certain (some) qualifications, the only policy, by which a republic can be administered on just principles." In ''Perpetual Peace: A Philosophical Sketch'' by Immanuel Kant (1795), Appendix one, ''Divide et impera'' is the third of three political maxims, the others being ''Fac et excusa'' (Act now, and make excuses later) and ''Si fecisti, nega'' (when you commit a crime, deny it).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.constitution.org/kant/append1.htm |title=Immanuel Kant: Perpetual Peace: Appendix I |publisher=Constitution.org |date= |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref>
Elements of this technique involve: * creating or encouraging divisions among the subjects to prevent alliances that could challenge the sovereign * aiding and promoting those who are willing to cooperate with the sovereign * fostering distrust and enmity between local rulers * encouraging meaningless expenditures that reduce the capability for political and military spending
Historically, this strategy was used in many different ways by empires seeking to expand their territories.
The concept is also mentioned as a strategy for market action in [[economics]] to get the most out of the players in a competitive market.
==Narcissism== {{Main article|Narcissism|Narcissistic parent|Narcissism in the workplace}} A primary strategy the narcissist uses to assert [[Abusive power and control|control]], particularly within his/her family, is to create divisions among individuals. This weakens and [[Isolation to facilitate abuse|isolates]] them, making it easier for the narcissist to [[Psychological manipulation|manipulate]] and dominate. Some are favoured, others are [[scapegoated]]. Such dynamics can play out in a workplace setting.<ref> Hall J [http://narcissistfamilyfiles.com/2017/03/27/its-you-and-me-baby-narcissist-head-games/ It’s You and Me Baby: Narcissist Head Games] The Narcissist Family Files 27 Mar 2017</ref>
==Psychopathy in the workplace== {{Main article|Psychopathy in the workplace}} Clive R. Boddy found that "divide and conquer" was a common strategy by corporate [[psychopaths]] used as a smokescreen to help consolidate and advance their grip on power in the corporate hierarchy.<ref name=Boddy>Boddy, C. R. [https://books.google.com/books?id=C0l9DAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Corporate Psychopaths: Organizational Destroyers] (2011)</ref>
==Historical examples==
===Africa=== The divide and conquer strategy was used by foreign countries in parts of [[Africa]] during the [[Scramble for Africa|colonial]] and post-colonial period. * Germany and [[Belgium]] ruled [[Rwanda]] and [[Burundi]] in a colonial capacity. Germany used the strategy of divide and conquer by placing members of the already dominant [[Tutsi]] minority in positions of power. When Belgium took over colonial rule in 1916, the Tutsi and [[Hutu]] groups were rearranged according to race instead of occupation. Belgium defined "Tutsi" as anyone with more than ten cows or a long nose, while "Hutu" meant someone with less than ten cows and a broad nose. The socioeconomic divide between Tutsis and Hutus continued after independence and was a major factor in the [[Rwandan Genocide]]. * During [[British Colony and Protectorate of Nigeria|British]] rule of [[Nigeria]] from 1900 to 1960, different regions were frequently reclassified for administrative purposes. The conflict between the [[Igbo people|Igbo]] and [[Hausa people|Hausa]] made it easier for the British to consolidate their power in the region.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyworld.net/wrldhis/PlainTextHistories.asp?historyid=ad41|title=HISTORY OF NIGERIA|work=historyworld.net}}</ref>
===Asia===
====Mongolian Empire==== * While the Mongols imported Central Asian Muslims to serve as administrators in China, the Mongols also sent Han Chinese and Khitans from China to serve as administrators over the Muslim population in Bukhara in Central Asia, using foreigners to curtail the power of the local peoples of both lands. Pakistan and India were also divided by this policy.<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=41930343|journal=Journal of Asian History|title=SINO-KHITAN ADMINISTRATION IN MONGOL BUKHARA|last=BUELL|first=PAUL D.|volume= 13|number=2|date=1979|pages=137–8|publisher=Harrassowitz Verlag}}</ref>
====Indian subcontinent==== The strategy of "Divide and Rule" was employed by most imperial powers in [[Indian subcontinent]]. The British and French backed various Indian states in conflicts between each other, both as a means of undermining each other's influence and consolidating their authority. The [[Durrand line]] divided [[Afghanistan]] and Northwest [[Pakistan]], the homeland of the [[Pashtuns]].
Further, it is argued that the British used the strategy to destroy the harmony between various religions and use it for their benefits<ref>Shashi Tharoor - Inglorious Empire What the British Did to India</ref>; a ''Times Literary Supplement'' review suggests that although this was broadly the case a more nuanced approach might be closer to the facts<ref>Jon Wilson, 2016, ''India Conquered: Britain's Raj and the chaos of empire'', cited in a review of Tharoor's work by Elizabeth Buettner in "Debt of Honour: why the European impact on India must be fully acknowledged", ''Times Literary Supplement'', August 11 2017, pages 13-14.</ref>.
====Middle East==== * The [[Sykes-Picot Agreement]], which carved the Middle East, is an example of a 'divide and rule' strategy. * Some analysts assert that the US is practicing the strategy in the 21st century middle east through escalation of the [[Sunni-Shia conflict]]. [[Nafeez Ahmed]] cites a 2008 [[RAND Corporation]] study for the American military which recommended "divide and rule" as a possible strategy against the Muslim world in "[[War on Terror#Etymology|the Long War.]]" <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pernin|first=Christopher G., et al|date=2008|title=Unfolding the Future of the Long War|url=https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/monographs/2008/RAND_MG738.pdf|journal=US Army Training and Doctrine Command’s Army Capability Integration Center|volume=|pages=|via=RAND Arroyo}}</ref> Dr. [[Christopher Davidson]] argues that the current [[Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)|crisis in Yemen]] is being “egged on” by the US, and could be part of a wider covert strategy to “spur fragmentation in Iran allies and allow Israel to be surrounded by weak states”.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/columns/pentagon-plan-divide-and-rule-muslim-world-1690265165|title=The Pentagon plan to ‘divide and rule’ the Muslim world|work=Middle East Eye|access-date=2018-06-29|language=en}}</ref>
===Europe=== * Romans entered [[Macedonia (ancient kingdom)|Macedonia]] from the south and defeated King [[Perseus of Macedon]] in the [[Battle of Pydna]] in 168 BC. Macedonia was then divided into four republics that were heavily restricted from relations with one another and other Hellenic states. A ruthless purge occurred, with allegedly anti-Roman citizens being denounced by their compatriots and deported in large numbers. * During the [[Gallic Wars]], [[Julius Caesar]] was able to use a divide and rule strategy to easily defeat the militarily strong [[Gauls]]. By the time the Gauls united under [[Vercingetorix]], it was already too late for them.<ref name="EB_The_Roman_Conquest">{{cite web |url=http://global.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/215768/France/41196/The-press |title=France: The Roman conquest |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=[[Encyclopædia Britannica Online]] |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica (company)|Encyclopædia Britannica]] |access-date=April 6, 2015 |quote="Because of chronic internal rivalries, Gallic resistance was easily broken, though Vercingetorix's Great Rebellion of 52 bce had notable successes."}}</ref><ref name="The_first_triumvirate_and_the_conquest_of_Gaul">{{cite web |url=http://global.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/88114/Julius-Caesar/9735/The-first-triumvirate-and-the-conquest-of-Gaul |title=Julius Caesar: The first triumvirate and the conquest of Gaul |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=[[Encyclopædia Britannica Online]] |publisher=[[Encyclopædia Britannica (company)|Encyclopædia Britannica]] |access-date=February 15, 2015 |quote="Indeed, the Gallic cavalry was probably superior to the Roman, horseman for horseman. Rome's military superiority lay in its mastery of strategy, tactics, discipline, and military engineering. In Gaul, Rome also had the advantage of being able to deal separately with dozens of relatively small, independent, and uncooperative states. Caesar conquered these piecemeal, and the concerted attempt made by a number of them in 52 bce to shake off the Roman yoke came too late."}}</ref> * Following the [[October revolution]], the [[Bolsheviks]] engaged at various times in alliances with the [[Left Socialist-Revolutionaries]], some [[Anarchists#Russian Revolution|anarchists]], and various non-Russian ethnic [[nationalist]] groups, against the [[White movement]], [[Right Socialist-Revolutionaries]], and other anarchist and ethnic nationalist groups. This was done to establish the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (the Bolshevik party) as the sole legal party in the [[Soviet Union]]. Similar shifting alliances were played out amongst various dissident factions within the CPSU, such as the [[Workers Opposition]] and [[Left Communists]], with [[Joseph Stalin]] and his supporters gaining absolute power within the party by the mid-1920s. * The [[Salami strategy]] of Hungarian Communist leader, [[Mátyás Rákosi]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} * Alliances with various parties played a role in the Nazi ''[[Machtergreifung]]'' and ''[[Gleichschaltung]]'', the seizure and consolidation of total power by the [[National Socialist German Workers Party]]. The [[Enabling Act of 1933|Enabling Act]], which banned the [[Communist Party of Germany|Communist]] and [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|Social Democratic]] parties, was supported by the Nazis' coalition partner, the [[German National People's Party]], as well as by the [[Centre Party (Germany)|Centre Party]]. Several months later, all political parties in Germany were banned except for the NSDAP. * The [[British Empire]] urged the Britons in [[British Cyprus]] to stir up the [[Turkish people|Turkish]] minority in order to neutralize agitation from the [[Greeks]]<ref>{{cite book |last1=Grob-Fitzgibbon|first1=Benjamin|title=Imperial Endgame: Britain's Dirty Wars and the End of Empire|date=2011|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-30038-5|page=285}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Jordan|first1=Preston Lim|title=The Evolution of British Counter-Insurgency during the Cyprus Revolt, 1955–1959|date=2018|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783319916200|page=58}}</ref> The British colonial policy of “divide and rule” cultivated intentionally animosity between the Greek majority and the Turkish minority (18% of the population) in the island that remains [[Cyprus dispute|divided]] till today.<ref>{{cite web|title=International Justice: The Case of Cyprus|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/constantine-tzanos/international-justice-the_b_9934090.html|publisher=The [[HuffPost]]|accessdate=1 November 2017|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>

'''Dog spinning''' ({{lang-bg|тричане на куче(та)}}, ''trichane na kuche(ta)'') is a ritual that was traditionally practiced on the first day of [[Lent]] in the village of [[Brodilovo]] in southeastern [[Bulgaria]]. It is related to similar rituals used on this day at other villages, in which the dogs were whipped or beaten. The ritual is thought to have [[paganism|pagan]] origins<ref name="stclair">{{cite book | last1 = St. Clair | first1 = Stanislas Graham Bower | last2 = Brophy | first2 = Charles A. | title = A residence in Bulgaria | publisher = J. Murray | date = 1869 | location = London | pages = 39 | url = http://openlibrary.org/books/OL24240013M/A_residence_in_Bulgaria }}</ref> and was performed in order to prevent [[rabies]].<ref name="darik">{{cite news | last = Ameleva | first = Iveta | title = Кмет забрани жесток обичай с кучета | newspaper = Darik News | language = Bulgarian | date = 2006-02-23 | url = http://www.darik.net/view_article.php?article_id=48579 | accessdate = 2015-01-29 }}</ref>
In dog spinning, a [[dog]] is suspended above water on a rope. The dog is turned repeatedly in a given direction to wind the rope, or is inserted into a loop of rope that has been twisted already. The dog is then released so that it spins rapidly in the opposite direction as the rope unwinds.
== History == Historically the ritual was performed in many other parts of [[Bulgaria]] as well and although the exact practice varied regionally, e.g. whipping or beating the dogs instead of spinning them, it was performed on the same date and with the same goal. Reports of this type of ritual can be found as early as 1869.<ref name="stclair" />
== Animal welfare concerns == The Swedish newspaper [[Aftonbladet]] reported protests at the Bulgarian Embassy in Stockholm about the cruelty of this tradition. These occurred as Bulgaria prepared to join the [[European Union]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite news | last = Ovander | first = Petter | title = Barbarer! | newspaper = Aftonbladet | language = Swedish | date = 2005-03-08 | url = http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article10557377.ab | accessdate = 2015-01-29 }}</ref>
A reference in English is in a press release issued by the [[Green Party of England and Wales|UK Green Party]], issued on July 29, 2005. It includes a statement from Green Party [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] [[Caroline Lucas]], vice-president of the [[RSPCA]] and the European Parliament's cross-party Animal Welfare Intergroup. Dr Lucas criticised it as being cruel to dogs, saying "Dog-spinning is a barbaric practice and must not be allowed to continue into the 21st century."
The "Sofia Echo" reported the practice in March 2011.
The practice of the ritual was banned by the mayor of [[Tsarevo]] in 2006<ref name="darik" /><ref>{{cite news | last = Bozhkov | first = Bozhidar | title = Забраниха жестокия ритуал с кучета в Странджа | newspaper = Сега | language = Bulgarian | date = 2006-02-24 | url = http://www.segabg.com/online/article.asp?issueid=2155&sectionid=2&id=0000603 | accessdate = 2015-01-29 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110928215010/http://www.segabg.com/online/article.asp?issueid=2155&sectionid=2&id=0000603 | archivedate = 2011-09-28 | df = }}</ref> after complaints by Bulgarian [[animal welfare]] organizations.<ref>[http://www.iwns.org/content/view/167/64/lang,bg/ Сигнал във връзка с "тричане на куче", 15.03.2005] (in [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]])</ref> There have been reports of the practice continuing sporadically, and animal welfare organisations have tried to ensure this does not happen.<ref>{{cite news | last = Smith | first = Graham | title = Exposed: The cruel dog-spinning ritual to 'ward off rabies' that is STILL being practised Bulgaria | newspaper = Mail Online | date = 2012-02-29 | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2107697/Bizarre-dog-spinning-ritual-ward-rabies-practised-rural-Bulgaria-despite-banned-thwarted-animal-rights-activists.html | accessdate = 2015-01-29}}</ref>{{Better source|date=May 2017}}<ref>{{cite news | title = Протести срещу тричането в интернет | newspaper = Burgasnews | date = 2015-01-26 | url = http://www.burgasnews.com/komentari/82611-protesti-sreshtu-trichaneto-v-internet | accessdate = 2015-01-29}}</ref>

{{Infobox television episode | title = Glee, Actually | series = [[Glee (TV series)|Glee]] | image = | caption = | season = 4 | episode = 10 | director = [[Adam Shankman]] | writer = Matthew Hodgson | music = {{Plainlist| *"[[Feliz Navidad (song)|Feliz Navidad]]" *"[[White Christmas (song)|White Christmas]]" *"[[Oh Chanukah|Hanukkah, Oh Hanukkah]]" *"[[Jingle Bell Rock]]" *"[[The First Noël]]" *"[[Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas]]"}} | production = 4ARC10 | airdate = {{start date|2012|12|13}} | guests = *[[Jessalyn Gilsig]] as [[Terri Schuester]] *[[Mike O'Malley]] as [[Burt Hummel]] *[[Dot Jones|Dot-Marie Jones]] as [[Shannon Beiste]] *[[Aisha Tyler]] as [[Characters of Glee#Other family of McKinley students and faculty|Jake's mother]] *[[Gina Hecht]] as [[Characters of Glee#Other family of McKinley students and faculty|Mrs. Puckerman]] *[[Melissa Benoist]] as [[Marley Rose]] *[[Jacob Artist]] as [[Jake Puckerman]] *[[Becca Tobin]] as [[Kitty Wilde]] *[[Blake Jenner]] as [[Ryder Lynn]] *[[Damian McGinty]] as [[Rory Flanagan]] *[[Samuel Larsen]] as [[Joe Hart (Glee)|Joe Hart]] *[[Lauren Potter]] as [[Becky Jackson]] *[[Trisha Rae Stahl]] as [[Millie Rose]] | prev = [[Swan Song (Glee)|Swan Song]] | next = [[Sadie Hawkins (Glee)|Sadie Hawkins]] | episode_list = List of Glee episodes | season_article = Glee (season 4) }} "'''Glee, Actually'''" is the tenth episode of the [[Glee (season 4)|fourth season]] of the American musical television series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'', and the seventy-sixth episode overall as well as the show's third Christmas-themed episode. Written by Matthew Hodgson and directed by Adam Shankman, it aired on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] in the United States on December 13, 2012.
The episode garnered mixed reviews from critics; and was watched by 5.26 million viewers, receiving an 18-49 rating of 2.0.
==Plot== [[Artie Abrams]] ([[Kevin McHale (actor)|Kevin McHale]]) injures himself on an icy wheelchair ramp at McKinley High. [[Finn Hudson]] ([[Cory Monteith]]) helps him to the school nurse's office, where Artie tells Finn he wishes that the accident that paralyzed him had never happened. Artie falls asleep in the nurse's office and enters a [[dream sequence]]. In the dream, as explained by his guide [[Rory Flanagan]] ([[Damian McGinty]]), Artie was never paralyzed and as a result many of the events as he knows them never took place. The glee club never got off the ground, and [[Will Schuester]] ([[Matthew Morrison]]) has become an apathetic alcoholic under the control of his wife, [[Terri Schuester]] ([[Jessalyn Gilsig]]). [[Kurt Hummel]] ([[Chris Colfer]]) is bullied by jocks – including several of the glee club members – because of his homosexuality, and as a result never graduated from high school. [[Rachel Berry]] ([[Lea Michele]]) works as a librarian in the school library, having never had a chance to be a star. [[Becky Jackson]] ([[Lauren Potter]]) is the school slut because she was never treated with respect because Artie never took her on a date. Artie gathers the glee club as he knows it and performs "[[Feliz Navidad (song)|Feliz Navidad]]" in an attempt to inspire them to establish a glee club, but fails. Last, Rory informs Artie that [[Quinn Fabray]] ([[Dianna Agron]]) never managed to recover from her car accident, which happened regardless of her participation in the glee club, and, since she didn't have the support of her friends, died of a broken heart. Rory explains to Artie that wheelchair-bound Artie is the heart and soul of the glee club, and Artie wakes up from the dream with a better appreciation of his role in the club.
[[Burt Hummel]] ([[Mike O'Malley]]) surprises Kurt and Rachel by showing up at their New York apartment. Burt explains to Rachel the significance of Christmas in Kurt's life, especially after the death of Kurt's mother. Rachel goes on a cruise, while the Hummels continue to bond in New York. Burt reveals to Kurt that he has prostate cancer, but it was diagnosed at an early stage and his chances for survival are very high. Burt then surprises Kurt again by revealing that he has paid for [[Blaine Anderson]] ([[Darren Criss]]) to travel to New York to spend Christmas with them. They have an awkward but cordial reunion, and sing "[[White Christmas (song)|White Christmas]]". Back at the apartment, Burt, Kurt, and Blaine continue several of the Hummels' Christmas traditions, and have dinner.
[[Noah "Puck" Puckerman]] ([[Mark Salling]]) invites [[Jake Puckerman]] ([[Jacob Artist]]) to travel to Los Angeles with him. Puck tries to impress Jake with the lifestyle he lives in Los Angeles, but when the actual owner of the house where Puck told Jake he had been living returns home and kicks them out, Puck admits he has been lying about his lifestyle. The brothers return to Lima and later have a Hanukkah dinner at Breadstix, together with their respective mothers. The dinner goes badly at first, as the two women resent each other, but Puck and Jake convince their mothers that all four of them have a common bond: they were all placed into a difficult situation by Puck and Jake's father. The women begin to talk and soon start to bond. Puck informs Jake that he will be staying in Lima, while he works on a screenplay.
[[Brittany Pierce]] ([[Heather Morris]]) and [[Sam Evans]] ([[Chord Overstreet]]) reveal to each other that they believe in the [[2012 phenomenon|2012 Mayan apocalypse]]. Believing that the world is about to end, Brittany cashes out her savings and gives her friends expensive gifts, and Sam proposes to Brittany. Coach [[Shannon Beiste]] ([[Dot-Marie Jones]]) performs the wedding ceremony. When the apocalypse does not occur as expected, Sam and Brittany realize that they are still married, and meet Coach Beiste at Breadstix to ask for help. Beiste reveals that she is not actually qualified to perform weddings, and that they are not officially married. She did this because she didn't really want them to get married. Both Brittany and Sam are disappointed that the world didn't end, but they realized that it felt good being nice to others. Coach Beiste, feeling sorry for them, pretended that an archaeologist named [[Indiana Jones]] found a Mayan calendar predicting that the world would end on September 27, 2014. This lifted Brittany and Sam's spirits, who were delighted to find out that there was still time to tell others how they felt.
After failing to satisfy Becky with her Christmas gifts, [[Sue Sylvester]] ([[Jane Lynch]]) draws Millie Rose's ([[Trisha Rae Stahl]]) name in a Secret Santa event held among the McKinley High faculty and staff. Unsure what to get Millie, Sue happens upon a conversation between Millie and her daughter [[Marley Rose]] ([[Melissa Benoist]]). Marley wants to have a Christmas tree and at least some gifts, but Millie explains that they need to save money to pay a counselor to treat Marley for her eating disorder. After seeing this, Sue breaks into the Roses' home that night and surreptitiously leaves them a Christmas tree, several presents, and enough money to pay Marley's counselor. Becky reveals to Millie that Sue was behind the surprise when bribed by candy and Millie attempts to return the money, but Sue insists that Millie keep it. Millie then brings Sue to the auditorium, where several of the glee club members including Marley sing "[[Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas]]", joined in unison by the four glee clubbers singing in Breadstix and the two singing in the New York apartment.
==Production== Guest star [[Aisha Tyler]] appears in this episode as the mother of Jake Puckerman.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2012/11/04/glee-season-4-cast-aisha-tyler-jakes-mom/#more-377815|title=''Glee'' Exclusive: ''The Talk''{{'}}s Aisha Tyler to Guest Star as [Spoiler<nowiki>]</nowiki>'s Mother!|first=Michael|last=Ausiello|work=TVLine|date=November 4, 2012|accessdate=November 29, 2012}}</ref> Recurring guest stars include Kurt's father Burt Hummel (O'Malley),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/366908/spoiler-chat-scoop-on-glee-gossip-girl-new-girl-csi-modern-family-and-more |title=Spoiler Chat: Scoop on ''Glee, Gossip Girl, New Girl, CSI, Modern Family'' and More!|work=Watch with Kristin|publisher=E! Online|date=November 29, 2012|accessdate=November 29, 2012}}</ref> Will's ex-wife Terri Schuester (Gilsig), former glee club member Rory Flanagan (McGinty), football coach Shannon Beiste (Jones), glee club members [[Joe Hart (Glee)|Joe Hart]] ([[Samuel Larsen]]), Marley Rose (Benoist), Jake Puckerman (Artist), [[Kitty Wilde]] ([[Becca Tobin]]) and [[Ryder Lynn]] ([[Blake Jenner]]), cheerleader Becky Jackson (Potter), [[Noah Puckerman|Puck]]'s mother ([[Gina Hecht]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2012/11/06/supernatural-spoilers-glee-girl-meets-world/|title=Ask Ausiello: Spoilers on ''Supernatural, Girl Meets World, Glee, NCIS, Revenge, 30 Rock'' and More!|first=Michael|last=Ausiello|work=TVLine|date=November 6, 2012|accessdate=November 29, 2012}}</ref> and Marley's mother, whose first name is revealed to be Millie in this episode ([[Trisha Rae Stahl]]).
This episode includes six songs, all of which were released on the soundtrack album ''[[Glee: The Music, The Christmas Album, Volume 3]]'' on December 11, 2012. The songs are [[José Feliciano]]'s "[[Feliz Navidad (song)|Feliz Navidad]]" performed by McHale, the [[Irving Berlin]] classic "[[White Christmas (song)|White Christmas]]" performed by Criss and Colfer, the traditional song "[[Oh Chanukah|Hanukkah, Oh Hanukkah]]" performed by Artist and Salling, [[Bobby Helms]]' "[[Jingle Bell Rock]]" performed by Overstreet, the traditional carol "[[The First Noël]]" performed by Benoist, and "[[Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas]]", originally from the [[MGM]] film ''[[Meet Me in St. Louis]]'', performed by Benoist, Salling, Artist, Overstreet, Morris, Criss, Colfer, and the glee club members.<ref name="gleexmas3">{{cite web|url=http://www.gleethemusic.com/us/news/glee-music-christmas-album-vol-3-available-december-11|title= GLEE: THE MUSIC, THE CHRISTMAS ALBUM VOL. 3 AVAILABLE DECEMBER 11|work=Glee: The Music|publisher=Columbia Records|date=November 29, 2012|accessdate=November 29, 2012}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Ratings=== The episode was watched by 5.26 million American viewers, and received a 2.0/5 rating/share among adults 18-49. The show placed third in its timeslot behind ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]'' and ''[[Person of Interest (TV series)|Person of Interest]].''<ref>http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/12/14/thursday-final-ratings-the-vampire-diaries-adjusted-up-last-resort-two-and-a-half-men-person-of-interest-greys-anatomy-scandal-adjusted-down/161819/</ref> With DVR numbers, the episode was watched by 2.59 million viewers with a 2.0 rating, totaling 7.85 million viewers and a 3.2 rating.<ref>http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/12/31/live7-dvr-ratings-modern-family-leads-adults-18-49-ratings-and-tops-viewership-gains-private-practice-earns-biggest-percentage-gains-in-week-12/163366/</ref>
===Reviews=== The episode received mixed reviews from critics. Laurel Brown of ''[[Zap2it]]'' gave the episode a mixed review, and wrote, "If you were hoping (like me) that ''Glee'' would pay homage to the brilliance of ''[[Love Actually|Love, Actually]]'' in its holiday-themed 'Glee, Actually', you may have been sorely disappointed." She criticized the Marley storyline calling it "a bit of a snooze", but called Artie's dream segment "a strong (if insane) segment". The storyline that featured Kurt and Burt was characterized as "cheesy", though she called the Hummel duo and Blaine "just so darn sweet!"<ref>http://blog.zap2it.com/frominsidethebox/2012/12/glee-christmas-episode-recap-5-stories-in-search-of-some-holiday-cheer.html</ref>
Rae Votta of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' also gave the episode a mixed review, and noted, "The one truth of ''Glee'' is the Christmas episode always involves a plethora of holiday sweet with just a dash of WTF."<ref>http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1481384/glee-recap-christmas-brings-marriage-cancer-ice-skating-love-actually</ref>
==Music== {{Main|Glee: The Music, The Christmas Album, Volume 3}}
===Performances=== The songs performed in the episode were all featured on the Christmas album ''[[Glee: The Music, The Christmas Album, Volume 3]],'' which was released December 11, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Glee: The Music - The Christmas Album, Vol. 3|url=http://www.walmart.com/ip/22236153|work=Walmart.com|accessdate=17 November 2012}}</ref> Therefore, the songs were not sold as singles.
===Chart history=== The Christmas album debuted at number 20 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart.

{{advert|date=June 2017}} [[File:Ignite Talks Logo.png|thumb|Ignite Talks logo]] '''Ignite''' (Ignite Talks) is a series of events where speakers have five minutes to talk on a subject accompanied by 20 slides, for 15 seconds each, automatically advanced. Ignite started in Seattle, and it has spread to 350+ organizing teams in cities, universities, governments and companies who have hosted thousands of events.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Ignite co-founder Brady Forrest acquires the popular speaker series from O'Reilly Media - GeekWire|url = http://www.geekwire.com/2015/ignite-co-founder-brady-forrest-acquires-popular-speaker-series-from-oreilly-media/|website = GeekWire|accessdate = 2015-11-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Ignite has a new home - O'Reilly Radar|url = http://radar.oreilly.com/2015/11/ignite.html|website = radar.oreilly.com|accessdate = 2015-11-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = A New Start for Ignite|url = https://medium.com/@brady/a-new-start-for-ignite-2a35a25288c1|website = Medium|accessdate = 2015-11-23}}</ref><ref name=tc>{{Cite web|title = Community Speaker Series Ignite Gets A Reboot|url = https://techcrunch.com/2015/11/16/letsbecyborganthropologists/|website = TechCrunch|accessdate = 2015-11-23|first = Sarah|last = Buhr}}</ref>
Ignite Talks is similar in its form to and probably inspired by [[PechaKucha]], found 12 years earlier.
The first Ignite was held in 2006 in [[Seattle, Washington]] by Brady Forrest and [[Bre Pettis]], and was sponsored by [[O'Reilly Media]] and ''[[Make (magazine)|MAKE]]'' magazine.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/03/fashion/03webparty.html?_r=2&ref=fashion&oref=slogin|title=Night Life Reprogrammed|last=Salkin |first=Allen |date=August 3, 2008|work=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=2008-08-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/business/405192_IGNITE16.html|title=A Seattle geek fest spreads its wings|last=Guzman |first=Monica |date=April 16, 2009|work=[[Seattle Post Intelligencer]]|accessdate=2009-04-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazettetimes.com/news/local/sharing-ideas-quickly/article_e9a05236-0fb1-5054-b917-f62a6e0ac85b.html|title=Sharing ideas quickly|last=Neznanski|first=Matt|date=November 14, 2008|work=[[Corvallis Gazette Times]]|accessdate=2008-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://igniteshow.com/howto|title=Testing How-to Layout|work=igniteshow.com|accessdate=12 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://venturebeat.com/2007/04/16/ignite-lights-up-web-20-expo/ |title=Ignite Lights Up Web 2.0 Expo |work=VentureBeat }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2008/02/attention_deficit_theater.html |title=Attention Deficit theater |date= February 5, 2008 |last=Oppenheimer |first=Laura |work=[[The Oregonian]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.seattlepi.nwsource.com/thebigblog/archives/132223.asp |title=Ignite Seattle 5: Big ideas and really fast talking hit Capitol Hill |work=[[Seattle Post Intelligencer]] |last=Guzman |first=Monica |date=February 19, 2008 }}</ref> O'Reilly continued to support Ignite until November 2015 when the franchise was handed off to its founder, Brady Forrest, who formed Ignite Talks, PBC - a [[Public-benefit corporation|Public Benefit Corporation]]. Ignite Talks PBC was formed to be an independent organization focusing on supporting Ignite events around the world and promoting public speaking.<ref name=tc/>
