{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name= Phillip John Lamason |birth_date=15 September 1918 |death_date= {{Death date and age|df=y|2012|5|19|1918|9|15}} |birth_place=[[Napier, New Zealand]] |death_place= [[Dannevirke]], New Zealand |image=Phil Lamason.jpg |caption= Squadron Leader Phil Lamason c. 1942 |allegiance={{flag|New Zealand}} |serviceyears= 1940–1945 |rank= [[Squadron Leader]] |branch= {{air force|New Zealand}} |unit= [[No. 218 Squadron RAF]]
[[No. 15 Squadron RAF]] |battles= [[Second World War]] |awards=[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] [[Medal bar|& Bar]]
[[Mentioned in Despatches]] (2) |laterwork=Farmer
[[Stock transfer agent|Stock agent]] }} '''Phillip John Lamason''' [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|DFC]] [[Medal bar|& Bar]] (15 September 1918 – 19 May 2012) was a [[aviator|pilot]] in the [[Royal New Zealand Air Force]] (RNZAF) during the [[Second World War]], who rose to prominence as the [[Commanding officer|senior officer]] in charge of 168 [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] airmen taken to [[Buchenwald concentration camp]], Germany, in August 1944. Raised in Napier, he joined the RNZAF in September 1940, and by April 1942 was a [[pilot officer]] serving with the [[Royal Air Force]] in [[European Theatre of World War II|Europe]]. On 8 June 1944, Lamason was in command of a [[Avro Lancaster|Lancaster]] heavy bomber that was shot down during a raid on railway marshalling yards near [[Paris]]. [[Parachute|Bailing out]], he was picked up by members of the [[French Resistance]] and hidden at various locations for seven weeks. While attempting to reach Spain along the [[Comet line]], Lamason was double-crossed by a [[Treason|traitor]] within the Resistance and handed over to the [[Gestapo]]. After [[interrogation]], he was taken to [[Fresnes prison]]. Classified as a "Terrorflieger" (terror flier), he was not accorded [[prisoner-of-war]] (POW) status, but instead treated as a criminal and spy. By 15 August 1944, Lamason was [[Military rank#Field or senior officers|senior officer]] of a group of 168 captured Allied airmen who were taken by train to Buchenwald concentration camp, arriving there five days later. At Buchenwald, the airmen were fully shaved, [[Starvation|starved]], denied shoes, and for three weeks forced to sleep outside without shelter in one of the sub-camps known as "Little Camp". As senior officer, Lamason took control and instilled a level of [[Military courtesy|military discipline]] and bearing. For several weeks Lamason negotiated with the camp authorities to have the airmen transferred to a POW camp, but his requests were denied. At great risk, Lamason secretly got word to the [[Luftwaffe]] of the Allied airmen's captivity and, seven days before their scheduled [[Capital punishment|execution]], 156 of the 168 prisoners were transferred to [[Stalag Luft III]]. Most of the airmen credit their survival at Buchenwald to the leadership and determination of Lamason. After the war, he moved to [[Dannevirke]] and became a farmer until his retirement. During the 1980s and 1990s, he was a regular speaker at [[KLB Club]] and POW reunions. ==Early career== Lamason was born and raised in [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]], a city in New Zealand's [[North Island]], on 15 September 1918.Thompson, H. L. (1953). [https://books.google.com/books?id=HSlAOwAACAAJ&dq ''New Zealanders with the Royal Air Force. (Vol. 1)'']. Published by War History Branch, Dept. of Internal Affairs, Wellington. {{OCLC|270919916}}. He was educated at [[Napier Boys' High School]] and [[Massey University]] ([[Palmerston North]] campus) where he was awarded a [[Diploma]] in [[Sheep husbandry|Sheepfarming]].[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19371211.2.18&srpos= Massey College: Diplomas and Prizes], ''New Zealand Evening Post'', Volume CXXIV, Issue 141, page 7, date 11 December 1937; retrieved 6 May 2012. During this period, Lamason described himself as "a bit of a ratbag".[http://www.hawkesbaytoday.co.nz/news/phil-lamason-anzac-day/1357384/ Anzac Day: From teen ratbag to hero], hawkesbaytoday.co.nz, 25 April 2012; retrieved 2 May 2012. Prior to the war, he worked for the Department of Agriculture at [[New Plymouth]] as a stock inspector.[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19440805.2.42&srpos=2&e AWARD OF BAR TO D.F.C]. Evening Post, Volume CXXXVIII, Issue 31, pg. 6, date 5 August 1944; retrieved 26 April 2011. It was there Lamason took the opportunity of free flying lessons, clocking up 100 hours. He was described as a tall, good-looking man with blue eyes and a broken nose.Burgess, Colin (1995). [https://books.google.com/books?id=jqKyAAAACAAJ&dq ''Destination Buchenwald'']. Published by Kangaroo Press, Kenthurst NSW. {{OCLC|35019954}}. {{ISBN|0-86417-733-X}} Lamason joined the RNZAF in September 1940. By April 1942, he had been posted to the [[European Theatre of World War II|European theatre of operations]] as a [[pilot officer]] in [[No. 218 Squadron RAF]]. During a bombing raid on [[Plzeň|Pilsen]], Czechoslovakia, he was in command of an aircraft that was attacked by an enemy fighter and badly damaged, but managed to return to base. As a result of his actions, he was awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] (DFC) on 15 May 1942.[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19420516.2.60&srpos=2&e Skill and Gallantry]. Evening Post, Volume CXXXIII, Issue 114, pg. 6, date 16 May 1942; retrieved 26 May 2011. The citation read: [[File:AVRO Lancaster LM575 LS-H Crew.jpg|thumb|left|Lamason (third from right) and his crew standing in front of their Lancaster heavy bomber; early 1944.]] {{quote|Pilot Officer Philip John. LAMASON, (N.Z. 403460), Royal New Zealand Air Force, No. 218 Squadron. One night in April, 1942, this officer was the captain of an aircraft which attacked Pilsen. During the return flight his aircraft was attacked by an enemy fighter and sustained damage; the hydraulics were shot away and the turret rendered unserviceable, while a fire broke out in the middle of the fuselage. Displaying great presence of mind, Pilot Officer Lamason coolly directed his crew in the emergency and, while 2 of them dealt with the fire, he skilfully outmanoeuvred his attacker and finally shook him off. By his fine airmanship and great devotion to duty, Pilot Officer Lamason was undoubtedly responsible for the safe return of the aircraft and its crew. This officer has completed 21 sorties and he has at all times displayed courage and ability.{{London Gazette|issue=35560|supp=y|page=2121|date=12 May 1942}}}} After his first tour ended flying [[Short Stirling|Stirlings]] with 218 Squadron, Lamason then instructed other pilots at [[List of Royal Air Force Conversion Units|1657 Heavy Conversion Unit]]. Returning to operations with [[No. 15 Squadron RAF]], Lamason was twice [[Mentioned in Despatches]], first on 2 June 1943 and again, having received promotion to acting [[squadron leader]], on 14 January 1944.{{London Gazette|issue=36033|supp=y|pages=2453–2457|date=28 May 1943}}{{London Gazette|issue=36329|pages=286–291|date=28 May 1943}} He was awarded a [[medal bar|Bar]] to his DFC on 27 June 1944, for "courage and devotion to duty of a high order" and "vigorous determination" in attacks on [[Berlin]] and other heavily defended targets.{{London Gazette|issue=36584|supp=y|page=3044|date=23 June 1943}} Lamason was presented his award after the war by [[King George VI]] at [[Buckingham Palace]], where he met and befriended a young [[Elizabeth II|Princess Elizabeth]].Chatterton, Tracey (26 May 2012). [http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/news/obituaries/6993965/War-hero-had-a-core-of-steel "War hero had 'core of steel'"], ''The Dominion Post''; retrieved 26 May 2012. A day after making an [[emergency landing]] at an American base in England, Lamason was introduced to, shook hands and spoke with [[Clark Gable]]. Lamason was not afraid to speak his mind. On the night of 30/31 March 1944, when 795 bombers were sent to attack [[Battle of Berlin (air)#Timeline|Nuremberg]], he was very critical of the route chosen, warning his [[station commander]] that heavy losses could be expected.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/9303440/Squadron-Leader-Phil-Lamason.html Squadron Leader Phil Lamason obituary], Telegraph.co.uk, 1 June 2012; retrieved 1 June 2012. On the moonlit night, 95 bombers were lost, its heaviest losses of the entire war during a single raid.[http://www.raf.mod.uk/history/rafhistorytimeline1944.cfm RAF Timeline 1944], raf.mod.uk' retrieved 17 June 2012. ==Buchenwald== On 8 June 1944, Lamason was serving as a [[flight (military unit)|flight]] commander in a [[Avro Lancaster|Lancaster]] LM575 LS-H[http://www.lostaircraft.com/database.php?lang=en&mode=viewentry&e=12861 Record for Lancaster LM575 on ''lostaircraft.com''] of [[No. 15 Squadron RAF]], on his 45th operation, when he was shot down during a raid on railway marshalling yards at [[Gare de Massy – Palaiseau|Massy-Palaiseau]] near [[Paris]].[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19450525.2.25 ''In Gestapo Hands'']. [[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post (Wellington, NZ)]], Volume CXXXIX, Issue 122, pg 4, 25 May 1945; retrieved 22 September 2010. Lamason recalled: {{quote|On the night of the raid our bomber was spotted by a German fighter, which locked on to it. I decided to turn and fight him. Within seconds an incendiary round hit a wing and caught the fuel tank. I gave the order to bail out as the gas torched. But Robbie, our mid-upper gunner, kept on firing. When he eventually did jump, we no longer had enough height. I saw his parachute open, but too late. He must have died on impact. I pushed the navigator out and managed to jump clear at the last minute.Eden, Richard & Oakes, John (2001). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1374126/French-never-forgot-lost-wartime-airman.html French never forgot 'lost' wartime airman], telegraph.co.uk; retrieved 4 January 2009.}} [[File:Dannevirke's Phil Lamason.jpg|thumb|right|Lamason in the pilot's seat of the cockpit of a Sterling Bomber in 1942]] Along with his English [[navigator]], [[Flying Officer]] Ken Chapman, Lamason was picked up by members of the [[French Resistance]] and hidden at various locations for seven weeks.Hancock, Kenneth (1946, p. 96). [https://books.google.com/books?id=LyPTAAAAMAAJ&q ''New Zealand at war'']. A.H. and A. W. Reed (publishers), Wellington, NZ. {{OCLC|153784576}}. In August 1944, while attempting to reach [[Spain]] along the [[Comet line]], Lamason and Chapman were captured by the [[Gestapo]] in Paris after they were [[betrayal|betrayed]] by the French [[double agent]] [[Jacques Desoubrie]] for 10,000 [[French franc|francs]] each.McKay, Christine. [http://www.hawkesbaytoday.co.nz/news/phil-lamason-humble-bay-pilot/1357378/ Phil Lamason: Humble Bay pilot], . HawkesBayToday.co.nz, 25 April 2012; retrieved 2 May 2012. After [[interrogation]] at the Gestapo headquarters in Paris, they were taken to [[Fresnes Prison]]. Many fliers were classified as "Terrorflieger" (terror flier) by the Germans, and were not given a trial. The most common act for allied airmen to be classified a terror flier was to be captured in civilian clothing and/or without their [[Dog tag (military)|dog tags]]. The [[Federal Foreign Office (Germany)|German Foreign Office]] decided that these captured enemy airmen should not be given the legal status of [[prisoner of war]] (POWs) but should instead be treated as criminals and spies.Veterans Affairs Canada (2006). [http://www.vac-acc.gc.ca/remembers/sub.cfm?source=history/secondwar/fact_sheets/pow ''Prisoners of War in the Second World War''], vac-acc.gc.ca; retrieved 6 January 2009.National Museum of the USAF (2008). [http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?fsID=15151 ''Fact Sheets: Allied Victims of the Holocaust''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015121919/http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?fsID=15151 |date=15 October 2012 }}, nationalmuseum.af.mil; retrieved 5 January 2009. Consequently, Lamason was among a group of 168 allied airmen from [[Royal Air Force|Great Britain]], [[United States Air Force|United States]], [[Royal Australian Air Force|Australia]], [[Royal Canadian Air Force|Canada]], [[Royal New Zealand Air Force|New Zealand]] and [[Jamaica]] who—along with over 2,500 French prisoners—were taken by train—in overcrowded [[Boxcar|cattle boxcars]] — from Fresnes Prison outside Paris, to [[Buchenwald concentration camp]]. As the airmen were herded into the boxcars, Lamason protested about the poor treatment of the airmen, only to be struck in the face by a [[SS-Totenkopfverbände|SS guard]].{{#tag:ref|The day Lamason was struck by a SS guard is disputed. In the books ''Destination Buchenwald'' (p. 66), ''In the Shadows of War'' (pp. 233, 256) and ''Night After Night'' (p. 466), all authors stated that Lamason was hit by the guard on the first day, at the railway station outside Paris, as the airmen were herded into the boxcars. However, in an article in the New Zealand ''Evening Post'', Lamason stated that he was hit by the SS guard the day after a French teenage boy was taken off the train and executed by the guards, during the five-day journey to Buchenwald.|group=note}} Lamason fell to the ground and captured pilot [[Roy Allen]] watched as a [[Sturmbannführer|SS Major]] pulled a [[Luger P08 pistol|Luger]] from his holster and thought Lamason would be shot on the spot.Childers, Thomas (2004). [https://books.google.com/books?id=DbyjREeuE78C&dq ''In the Shadows of War''], Henry Holt and Co, New York. {{OCLC|50559805}} {{ISBN|0-8050-5752-8}} After five days travel, during which the airmen received very little food or water, they arrived at Buchenwald on 20 August 1944.Lambert, Max (2005, pp. 464-68). [https://books.google.com/books?id=_71BAAAACAAJ&dq ''Night After Night: New Zealanders in Bomber Command''], Harper Collins, Auckland. {{OCLC|238569316}}. {{ISBN|1-86950-542-5}}Kinnis, Arthur and Booker, Stanley (1999). [https://books.google.com/books?id=-rvKAAAACAAJ&dq ''168 Jump Into Hell''], Victoria B.C. {{OCLC|43390724}}. {{ISBN|0-9684198-0-1}}{{#tag:ref|During train stops to Buchenwald, Lamason emerged as the leader of the group and assumed command (Robb, 2009). However, it was not until the 168 airmen arrived at Buchenwald that it was firmly established that Lamason was the senior Allied officer. After Lamason, the senior Commonwealth officer was Flight Lieutenant Tom Blackham, and the senior US officer was Captain Merle Larson (Kinnis, p. 85).|group=note}} [[File:Lamason's Lancaster on fire.jpg|thumb|left|German footage of Lamason's Lancaster bomber on fire on 8 June 1944]] Buchenwald was a [[Nazi concentration camps|labour camp]] of about 60,000 inmates of mainly [[Russians|Russian]] POWs, but also common criminals, religious prisoners (including [[Jews]]), and various [[political prisoner]]s from [[Germany]], [[France]], [[Poland]], and [[Czechoslovakia]].Crocker, Brandon (2008). [http://spectator.org/archives/2004/06/04/an-american-in-buchenwald An American in Buchenwald] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201024957/http://www.spectator.org/archives/2004/06/04/an-american-in-buchenwald |date=1 December 2008 }}. ''The American Spectator''. Retrieved on 4 January 2009. It was known for its brutality and barbaric [[Nazi human experimentation|medical experiments]].[http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10005198 Buchenwald] (2010). United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington; retrieved 25 August 2010. Upon arrival, Lamason, as ranking officer, demanded an interview with the camp [[commandant]], [[Hermann Pister]], which he was granted. He insisted that the airmen be treated as POWs under the [[Geneva Conventions]] and be sent to a [[Prisoner-of-war camp|POW camp]]. The commandant agreed that their arrival at Buchenwald was a "mistake" but they remained there anyway. The airmen were given the same poor treatment and beatings as the other inmates. For the first three weeks at Buchenwald, the prisoners were totally shaved, denied shoes and forced to sleep outside without shelter in one of Buchenwald's sub-camps, known as 'Little Camp'.Marshall, Bruce (2000, pp. 193-94). [https://books.google.com/books?id=542KQgAACAAJ&dq ''The White Rabbit'']. Published by Cassell, London. {{OCLC|59575058}} {{ISBN|0-304-35697-2}}Dyreborg, Erik (2003, pp. 287-93). [https://books.google.com/books?id=eqNcNLPb_ZMC&printsec ''The young ones: American airmen of WW II'']. Published by iUniverse, Inc., Lincoln, NE. {{OCLC|54444615}} {{ISBN|0-595-28237-7}} Little Camp was a [[quarantine]] section of Buchenwald where the prisoners received the least food and harshest treatment.Moser, Joseph and Baron, Gerald (2009). [https://books.google.com/books?id=kMk6PgAACAAJ&dq ''A fighter pilot in Buchenwald'']. Published by Edens Veil Media, Bellingham, WA. {{OCLC|311551716}}. {{ISBN|978-0-615-22111-3}}[http://www.vac-acc.gc.ca/general/sub.cfm?source=salute/spring2010/pow ''Canadian POWs Return to Buchenwald'']. Veterans Affairs Canada; retrieved 27 September 2010. After their first meal, Lamason stepped forward and said:{{quote|Attention!... Gentlemen, we have ourselves in a very fine fix indeed. The goons have completely violated the Geneva Convention and are treating us as common thieves and criminals. However, we are soldiers. From this time on, we will also conduct ourselves as our training has taught us and as our countries would expect from us. We will march as a unit to roll call and we will follow all reasonable commands as a single unit.Moser, Joe (2008). [http://buchenwaldflyboy.wordpress.com/chapter-8-buchenwald Buchenwald Flyboy: Chapter 8], buchenwaldflyboy.wordpress.com; retrieved 4 January 2009.}} [[File:Phil Lamason2.jpg|thumb|right|Lamason (centre) and another airman (Ken Chapman) playing chess in [[Chevreuse]] with a Frenchwoman whose family hid them for two weeks.]] Lamason then instructed the group not to trust the SS, or provoke them in any way because as they had experienced on the train, the guards were unpredictable and trigger-happy. Also, they were not to explore the camp because of the chance of [[Unspoken rule|breaking unknown rules]], but to stay together and keep as far away from the guards as possible.Harvie, John (1995). [https://books.google.com/books?id=1SdYB2rhzscC&printsec=frontcover&dq# ''Missing in Action'']. Published by McGill-Queen's University Press, Montreal. {{OCLC|34558799}}. {{ISBN|0-7735-1350-7}} He further stated that acting on the group's behalf, he would make further contact with the camp authorities for recognition of their rights.Monteath, Peter (2011, p. 292). [https://books.google.com/books?id=RsE1aSzSvMAC&pg ''P.O.W.: Australian Prisoners of War in Hitler's Reich'']. Published by Pan Macmillan, Sydney. {{OCLC|707720338}}. {{ISBN|978-1-74261-008-5}} Lamason then proceeded to organise the airmen into groups by nationality and appointed a [[Commanding officer]] within each group. Lamason did not do this just to improve their [[morale]] but because he also saw it as his responsibility to carry on his war duties despite the adverse circumstances. Captured US pilot Joe Moser believed that Lamason also did this because if the right opportunity presented itself, the group would be able to operate much more effectively if [[Military courtesy|military discipline]] and operations were applied. Lamason's leadership boosted the airmen's spirits and gave them hope while instilling a level of discipline and bearing. One of the first assignments Lamason gave was to mount a guard detail, both day and night, to prevent pilfering by other inmates, which had begun during their first night at camp. During their [[incarceration]], Lamason insisted the airmen [[Marching|march]], [[Military parade|parade]] and act as a [[military unit]].Taylor, Cliff (March 18, 2012). [http://www.lostairmen.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/New-Zealand-Herald-on-Sunday-March-18-2012.pdf "War Story: Lost Airmen of Buchenwald"], ''New Zealand Herald''; retrieved 18 May 2012. Within days of their arrival, Lamason met [[F.F.E. Yeo-Thomas|Edward Yeo-Thomas]], a [[Special Operations Executive|British spy]] being held at Buchenwald under the [[Pseudonym|alias]] Kenneth Dodkin. Lamason, who knew the real Dodkin quite well, immediately became suspicious and later confided in [[Christopher Burney]], who assured Lamason the cover was legitimate. Through Yeo-Thomas and Burney, Lamason was introduced to two Russian colonels, senior members of the [[Buchenwald Resistance|International Camp Committee]], an illegal [[Resistance during World War II|underground]] resistance group of prisoners in the main camp. As senior officer, Lamason had access to the main camp and quickly built a rapport with the group. As a result, he was able to secure extra blankets, clothes, [[Clog (shoe)|clogs]] and food for the airmen. Lamason also built a rapport with two other prisoners; [[French people|French]] scientist [[Alfred Balachowsky]] and Dutch [[Olympic Games|Olympian trainer]] Jan Robert. Both men had developed trustworthy contacts within the camp administrative area and were able to provide Lamason with reliable [[Military intelligence|intelligence]] that assisted in the survival of the airmen. [[File:Hermann Pister.jpg|thumb|left|110px|[[Hermann Pister]], Commandant of the camp while the allied airmen were prisoners there.]] For the next six weeks, Lamason negotiated with Pister and the German camp authorities, but his requests to have the airmen transferred to proper POW camps were denied.Australian War Memorial (2008). AWM Collection Record: P02988.001: [http://cas.awm.gov.au/photograph/P02988.001 Philip J. Lamason]. Retrieved 2009-01-04. One captured British airman, [[Pilot Officer]] Splinter Spierenburg, was a [[Dutch people|Dutchman]] flying for the [[Royal Air Force]].Air War Web Portal (2008). [http://www.airwarweb.net/dutch_raf.php Dutch Pilots in RAF Service: S.A. Spierenburg], airwarweb.net; retrieved 24 March 2009.[http://www.lostbombers.co.uk/bomber.php?id=9658 Lancaster ND921 Information] (2009). ''Lost Bombers During World War II''; retrieved 24 March 2009. Spierenburg, who spoke fluent [[German language|German]], regularly acted as an [[Interpreting|interpreter]] for Lamason when he negotiated with the camp authorities. As Buchenwald was a forced [[Nazi concentration camps|labor camp]], the German authorities had intended to put the 168 airmen to work as [[Forced labor in Germany during World War II|slave-labor]] in the nearby [[Otto Eberhardt Patronenfabrik|armament factories]].Stein, Harry (2004, p. 149). [https://books.google.com/books?id=d7WlV23kNoUC&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''Buchenwald concentration camp 1937-1945''], Göttingen: Wallstein. {{OCLC|61263627}}. {{ISBN|3-89244-695-4}} Consequently, Lamason was ordered by an SS officer to instruct the airmen to work, or he would be immediately [[Execution by firing squad|executed by firing squad]]. Lamason refused to give the order and informed the officer that they were soldiers and could not and would not participate in war production.Kahn, Dean (4 July 2011). [http://www.bellinghamherald.com/2011/07/04/2083577/movie-about-pilot-joe-mosers-story.html Movie about pilot Joe Moser's story of WWII survival to premier in Bellingham]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''The Bellingham Herald''; retrieved 3 October 2011. After a tense stand-off, during which time Lamason thought he would be shot, the SS officer eventually backed down.[http://vimeo.com/12449124 Phil Lamason - Refusal to work in Buchenwald Factories]. Mike Dorsey video interview with Phil Lamason (June 2010); retrieved 18 July 2010. Most airmen doubted they would ever get out of Buchenwald because their documents were stamped with the acronym "DIKAL" (Darf in kein anderes Lager), or "not to be transferred to another camp". At great risk, Lamason and Burney secretly smuggled a note through a trusted Russian prisoner, who worked at the nearby [[Nohra]] airfield, to the German [[Luftwaffe]] of their captivity at the camp.Perrin, Nigel (2008, pp. 149-50). [https://books.google.com/books?id=NkstAQAAIAAJ&q ''Spirit of resistance''], Pen & Sword Military, Barnsley, UK. {{OCLC|244653198}}. {{ISBN|978-1-84415-855-3}}[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10119086 Unsung heroes of the bombing war] (2005). ''The New Zealand Herald''. Retrieved on 13 January 2009. The message requested in part, that an officer pass the information to [[Berlin]], and for the Luftwaffe to intercede on behalf of the airmen. Lamason understood that the Luftwaffe would be sympathetic to their predicament, as they would not want their captured men treated in the same way; he also knew that the Luftwaffe had the political connections to get the airmen transferred to a POW camp.Blundell, Nigel (7 November 2011). [http://www.express.co.uk/features/view/282244/Sacrafice-of-Britain-s-bomber-boys {{sic|Sacrafice|expected=Sacrifice|nolink=y}} of Britain's Bomber Boys"], Express.co.uk; retrieved 10 November 2011. Eventually, Lamason's persistence paid off. Under the pretence of inspecting [[Bomb damage assessment|aerial bomb damage]] near the camp, two Luftwaffe officers (including [[Hannes Trautloft]]) made contact with the airmen and also spoke to Lamason.Makos, Adam (2013, pp. 316-18). [https://books.google.com/books?id=kXpFLgEACAAJ&dq ''A higher call''], Berkley Books, New York. {{OCLC|791682283}}. {{ISBN|9780425252864}}{{#tag:ref|The two Luftwaffe officers who went to Buchenwald were [[Inspector of the Day Fighters]], Colonel [[Hannes Trautloft]] and his [[adjutant]]. Trautloft was about to leave the camp when captured US airman Bernard Scharf called out to him in fluent German from behind a fence. The SS guards tried to intervene, but Trautloft pointed out that he out-ranked them and made them stand back. Scharf explained that he was one of more than 160 allied airmen imprisoned at the camp and begged Trautloft to rescue him and the other airmen. Disturbed by the event, Trautloft returned to Berlin and began the process to have the airmen transferred out of Buchenwald (Makos, pp. 316–18).|group=note}} Convinced the airmen were not spies, but bona-fide airmen, Trautloft reported his findings to [[Command (military formation)|command]]. After reading the report, an outraged [[Hermann Göring]] demanded 'at the highest level' the transfer of the airmen to Luftwaffe control. Unknown to all airmen except Lamason, their [[Capital punishment|execution]] had been scheduled for 26 October, if they remained at Buchenwald.Hope, Derek (2008). [http://www.airforce.mil.nz/operations/airforce-news/archive/93/flier-remembered.htm A flier is remembered]. ''Royal New Zealand Air Force''. Retrieved on 6 January 2009.Bard, Mitchell (2004, pp. 259-260). [https://books.google.com/books?id=8XexaFm8PuAC ''The Complete Idiot's Guide to World War II''], Alpha Books. {{OCLC|43803305}}. {{ISBN|1-59257-204-9}} News of the airmen's scheduled execution had been conveyed to Lamason by a German [[political prisoner]], [[Eugen Kogon]], who had a reliable contact within the camp administrative area.Kogon, Eugen (1980, p. 250). [https://books.google.com/books?id=xrQTAQAAIAAJ&q ''The theory and practice of hell: the German concentration camps and the system behind them''], Berkeley Books, California. {{OCLC|475381904}}. {{ISBN|978-0-425-04557-2}}{{#tag:ref|In the book ''The theory and practice of hell: the German concentration camps and the system behind them'', the author, Eugen Kogon, incorrectly refers to Lamason as an Australian.|group=note}} Lamason discussed the information at length with Yeo-Thomas, Burney and Robert and they concluded there was little that could be done to avert the mass execution. Lamason decided not to inform the airmen, but to keep this information to himself to keep [[morale#Military|morale]] high and in the slight hope the Luftwaffe would intervene in time. On the night of 19 October, seven days before their scheduled execution, 156 of the 168 airmen, including Lamason, were transferred from Buchenwald to [[Stalag Luft III]] by the Luftwaffe. {| class="wikitable" style="float:right;" |Nationalities of the 168 airmen[http://bulk.resource.org/gpo.gov/bills/105/hc95ih.txt.pdf 105th Congress] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100508192749/http://bulk.resource.org/gpo.gov/bills/105/hc95ih.txt.pdf |date=8 May 2010 }} (1997). Recognizing and commending American airmen held as political prisoners at the Buchenwald concentration camp. Retrieved on 11 January 2009.Stein, Harry (2004, p. 171). [https://books.google.com/books?id=d7WlV23kNoUC ''Buchenwald Concentration Camp 1937-1945'']. Published by Wallstein Verlag. {{OCLC|61263627}}. {{ISBN|3-89244-695-4}} |- |{{Flagicon|US}} 82 American |- |{{Flagicon|UK}} 48 British{{#tag:ref|Although Pilot Officer S.A. Spierenburg was a Dutchman flying for the RAF, he is listed in all material as a British national.|group=note}} |- |{{Flagicon|Canada|1921}} 26 Canadian |- |{{flagicon|Australia}} 9 Australian |- |{{flagicon|New Zealand}} 2 New Zealander |- |{{flagicon|Jamaica|variant=1906}} 1 Jamaican |} Two airmen died at Buchenwald. The other ten, who were too ill to be moved with the main group, were transported to Stalag Luft III in small groups over a period of several weeks.Little, Duncan (2009, p. 82). [https://books.google.com/books?id=J4nl2ofVmWQC&pg ''Allies in Auschwitz'']. Published by Clairview Books, East Sussex. {{OCLC|457167397}}. {{ISBN|978-1-905570-21-8}}. In the two months at Buchenwald, Lamason had lost 19 kilograms (42 [[Pound (mass)|lbs]]) and had contracted [[diphtheria]] and [[dysentery]]. At Stalag Luft III, he spent a month in the [[wikt:infirmary|infirmary]] recovering. In late January 1945, all Stalag Luft III POWs were [[The March (1945)|force-marched]] to other POW camps further inside Germany. Lamason and Chapman were marched to [[Stalag III-A]] outside [[Luckenwalde]], where they remained until liberated by the [[Soviet Union|Russian]] army at the [[End of World War II in Europe|end of the war in Europe]].[http://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/northland/local-news/392189 Airman survived horror camp] (2008). Dargaville News, New Zealand. Retrieved 2010-08-02Nichol, John and Rennell, Tony (2002). [https://books.google.com/books?id=d3YxGQAACAAJ&dq ''The last escape: the untold story of allied prisoners of war in Germany 1944 - 1945'']. Published by Viking Books, London. {{OCLC|231974289}}. {{ISBN|0-670-91094-5}}. Lamason and Chapman were taken to [[Hildesheim]] airfield and flown to [[City of Brussels|Brussels]] and then onto England.[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19450519.2.87&srpos=6&e Released Airmen]. Evening Post, Volume CXXXIX, Issue 117, 19 May 1945, Page 9. Retrieved 2011-04-27. Many airmen credit their survival at Buchenwald to the leadership and determination of Lamason. Captured pilot Stratton Appleman stated that "they were very fortunate to have Lamason as their leader". Another airman, Joe Moser, stated that Lamason was a great leader whom he would have been glad to follow anywhere he asked. British pilot James Stewart described Lamason as "a wonderful unsung hero".Esposito, Susan (March 9, 2012). [http://quoddytides.com/vet3-23-12.html ''Veteran remembers concentration camp ordeal'']. [[The Quoddy Tides]]; retrieved 6 May 2012. In the book ''168 Jump into Hell'', Lamason was described as having single-minded determination, selflessness, cold courage and forcefulness in the face of the threat of execution by the camp authorities because he was their leader and said that Lamason quickly established himself as a legendary figure in the airmen's eyes. In the [[National Film Board of Canada]] 1994 documentary, ''The Lucky Ones: Allied Airmen and Buchenwald'', captured pilot [[Tom Blackham]] stated that Lamason was not only the senior officer, but also their natural leader. Lamason emerged from Buchenwald with a giant reputation. In the book ''Destination Buchenwald'', Lamason stated he felt deeply honoured to have been the senior officer during the Buchenwald period. ==Aftermath and later life== Following their liberation and return to England, Lamason was asked to consider commanding one of the [[Tiger Force (air)|Okinawa]] squadrons for the final [[Operation Downfall|attack on Japan]]. However, the RNZAF refused and Lamason returned to New Zealand, arriving there the day after the [[Nuclear weapon|atomic bomb]] was dropped on [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|Hiroshima]]. After the war, Lamason was [[Military discharge|discharged]] from the air force on 16 December 1945.Hanson, C. M. (2001). [https://books.google.com/books?id=ehhNAQAACAAJ&dq ''By such deeds: honours and awards in the Royal New Zealand Air Force, 1923-1999''], Volplane Press, Christchurch, NZ. {{OCLC|155402329}}. {{ISBN|978-0-473-07301-5}} In 1946, Lamason was asked to be the lead pilot to test the flight paths for a new British airport. As part of the agreement, he was offered a farm in [[Berkshire]]. However, family said he needed to be home instead and [[Heathrow Airport]] went ahead without him. In 1948, Lamason moved to [[Dannevirke]], a small rural community north east of [[Palmerston North]] where he acquired 406 acres and became a [[farmer]] until his retirement. [[File:Phil Lamason Interview.jpg|thumb|left|Phil Lamason being interviewed in June 2010 by Mike Dorsey for the documentary film ''Lost Airmen of Buchenwald''.]] During the 1980s and 1990s, Lamason was a regular speaker at [[KLB Club|KLB (initials for Konzentrationslager Buchenwald) Club]] reunions, a club formed by the allied airmen while detained in Buchenwald.McDonald, Joanne (2005). [http://www.flamboroughreview.com/news/article/43662 ''POW survives horrors of Buchenwald concentration camp'']. Flamborough Review. Retrieved on 2010-08-18 Lamason was also a member of the [[Caterpillar Club]], an informal association of people who have successfully used a [[parachute]] to bail out of a disabled aircraft.Neal, John (2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=62tYKUBTRmQC&pg ''Bless you, Brother Irvin: the caterpillar club story''], General Store Publishing House, Ontario. {{OCLC|679837059}} {{ISBN|1-894263-94-4}} Lamason hid the fact for 39 years that the order for the airmen's execution was given and scheduled for 26 October 1944, first mentioning it at a Canadian POW convention in [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]] in 1983. In May 1987, the [[Government of New Zealand|New Zealand government]] in [[Wellington]] approved a fund to compensate servicemen held in German concentration camps and Lamason was awarded $13,000. However, Lamason was never formally honoured by his homeland for his leading role in saving the lives of the allied airmen at Buchenwald. In 1994, the [[National Film Board of Canada]] released a documentary movie titled, “''The Lucky Ones: Allied Airmen and Buchenwald''”, in which former Allied airmen recounted their personal and collective stories of life before, during and after Buchenwald.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0236456/ ''The Lucky Ones: Allied Airmen and Buchenwald'' (1994)], imdb.com; retrieved 17 July 2010. Lamason was interviewed and mentioned throughout the documentary.[http://onf-nfb.gc.ca/eng/collection/film/?id=30945 ''The Lucky Ones: Allied Airmen and Buchenwald''] (1994). National Film Board of Canada; retrieved 22 July 2010. Lamason was portrayed in the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel’s]] 2004 documentary "''Shot from the Sky''", about the real life saga of [[B-17 Flying Fortress|B-17]] pilot [[Roy Allen]], one of the captured airmen taken to Buchenwald.[https://www.imdb.com:80/title/tt0443640/ ''Shot from the Sky'' (2004)], imdb.com; retrieved 6 July 2017. In April 2005, Lamason, then 86, recollected the events of Buchenwald on [[Television New Zealand|TV New Zealand]].[http://tvnz.co.nz/view/news_national_story_skin/518820 Ex-RAF bomber remembers WWII] (2005). ''Television New Zealand Limited''. Retrieved on 15 February 2009. In June 2010, Lamason, then 91, was interviewed again about his experience at Buchenwald by Mike Dorsey. This and other interviews with Lamason are featured in Dorsey's 2011 documentary film titled, ''Lost Airmen of Buchenwald'', which tells the complete story of the 168 Allied airmen who were sent to Buchenwald, including Lamason.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1613036 ''Jump Into Hell'' (2011)], imdb.com; retrieved 6 July 2017.[http://buchenwaldflyboy.wordpress.com/2010/04/07/joe-moser-traveling-to-buchenwald-to-celebrate-liberation-and-film-documentary ''Joe Moser Traveling to Buchenwald to Celebrate Liberation and film documentary'']. Buchenwald Flyboy; retrieved 11 March 2011.Oppmann, Patrick (30 January 2009). [http://edition.cnn.com/2009/US/01/30/wwii.vet.honored/index.html ''World War II vet honored 60-plus years later for bombing mission'']. Cable News Network (CNN); retrieved 1 May 2011.Bratt, Calvin (14 April 2010). [http://lyndentribune.com/moser-in-germany-for-anniversary-of-buchenwalds-liberation-p317.htm?twindow=Default&smenu=1&mad=No ''Moser in Germany for anniversary of Buchenwald's liberation''] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120711002402/http://lyndentribune.com/moser-in-germany-for-anniversary-of-buchenwalds-liberation-p317.htm?twindow=Default&smenu=1&mad=No |date=11 July 2012 }}, Lynden Tribune; retrieved 1 May 2011. Mike Dorsey said Lamason remained scarred by his experiences to the extent that Dorsey said “I have a feeling that Lamason, to put it in a word, has no time for the Germans.”Hill, Graeme (24 May 2012). [http://www.radiolive.co.nz/The-shocking-and-moving-story-of-Kiwi-war-hero-and-Buchenwald-Concentration-Camp-survivor-Phil-Lamason/tabid/506/articleID/26713/Default.aspx The shocking and moving story of Kiwi war hero, and Buchenwald Concentration Camp survivor, Phil Lamason]. radiolive.co.nz; retrieved 24 May 2012. Lamason died at his home on 19 May 2012, on the farm outside Dannevirke where he had lived for over 60 years. He was 93 and at the time of his death, survived by two sons and two daughters. He was predeceased by his wife, Joan (née Hopkins), who died in 2009.Lambert, Max (May 20, 2012). [http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/6954700/Kiwi-World-War-II-hero-dies "Kiwi World War II hero dies"], Fairfax New Zealand Ltd; retrieved 20 May 2012. In November 2015, it was announced that a book recounting and honouring Lamason's life would be written by [[Waipukurau]] author Hilary Pedersen by September 2018 (what would have been Lamason's 100th birthday).McKay, Christine (November 23, 2015). [http://www.nzherald.co.nz/hawkes-bay-today/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503462&objectid=11549853 "''Dannevirke'': Book to follow airman's amazing life"], nzherald.co.nz; retrieved 1 December 2015.McKay, Christine (20 December 2016). [http://www.nzherald.co.nz/hawkes-bay-today/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503462&objectid=11769756 "Central Hawke's Bay war hero's story to be told"], nzherald.co.nz; retrieved 23 December 2016. The book titled, ''I Would Not Step Back ... The Phil Lamason Story'' was launched at Dannevirke in February 2018.McKay, Christine (December 4, 2017). {{update|date=March 2018}} '''Rajdowe Samochodowe Mistrzostwa Polski''' (RSMP) – the annual series of Polish Rally Championship existing from 1928. Consisting of several rounds on different surfaces throughout Poland. The organizer and owner of the cycle is [[Polski Związek Motorowy]] (PZM). In 2008 the main sponsor of the series is [[Orlen|Orlen oil]] company and its full name is Platinum Rajdowe Samochodowe Mistrzostwa Polski (Platinum Car Rally Championship Polish). A prerequisite for the start to RSMP is to have a rally license degree "R" or "R co-driver only" (entitles you to take off only as a co-driver). As of 2007, foreign drivers have been allowed to gain points. == History == Rallies in Poland almost always were at a high level of security and organisation ence have moved foreigners. The Second World War stopped high advancement of rallies. After the war Polish Rallies had problems. Just in 60s RSMP launched in high level. Great Polish drivers went to the conquest of Europe and [[Sobiesław Zasada]] has proved to be the best, he won three [[European Rally Championship]] titles (now [[World Rally Championship]]). He imported the latest sports cars, so he dominate of RSMP. In 1975 won title young driver [[Marian Bublewicz]] in [[Fiat 125|Polski Fiat 125p]] from [[Olsztyn]]. Since then RSMP won different drivers: [[Tomasz Ciecierzyński]], [[Włodzimierz Groblewski]], [[Jerzy Landsberg]], [[Błażej Krupa]], [[Maciej Stawowiak]], [[Tomasz Ciecierzyński]]. In 1980s for a title fight Marian Bublewicz and [[Andrzej Koper]]. They imported Japanese sports cars and [[Renault]]. Only in 1987 Bublewicz won championship in [[Polonez 2000]]. so it was amazing. In 1989–1992 Bublewicz had no equal. In 1993 he purchased [[Ford Escort Cosworth]] for next title, but new car was not ready for the first in season [[Rajd Dolnośląski|Zimowy Rajd Dolnośląski]]. He started in hired [[Ford Sierra]]. For unknown reasons, he lost car and hit in tree. Marian Bublewicz died in hospital. Polish fans and PZM were shocked. Bublewicz's fatal crash caused work on security. In 1990s for title going [[Paweł Przybylski]], [[Krzysztof Hołowczyc]], [[Robert Gryczyński]] and [[Janusz Kulig]]. {{Infobox Artwork | image_file= Lubo Kristek,Requiem für die Mobiltelephone.jpg | backcolor=#FBF5DF | painting_alignment=right | image_size=300px | title= Requiem for Mobile Telephones | artist=[[Lubo Kristek]] | year= 2007–2010 | medium=interactive [[Assemblage (art)|assemblage]] | height_metric=300 | width_metric=210 | length_metric=80 | metric_unit=cm | city= | museum= }} '''Requiem for Mobile Telephones'''Published in Neunzert 2008, p. 39. is an interactive [[Assemblage (art)|assemblage]]Putová 2013, p. 21. of the [[performance art|performance artist]] [[Lubo Kristek]] and also a series of his [[happening]]s. The artist started his happening series in 2007 to protest against the addictions to new technologies. He asked the audience to give up their mobile phones and use them to create an assemblage.Putová 2013, p. 121. == Background == The first action was held in the city of [[Znojmo]]. The spectators sewed the mobile phones directly on to the artist wearing a jacket with a train (the jacket then became the basis for new assemblage). The second happening took place in public area – on the pavement of Mariahilfer Straße in [[Vienna]] in 2007. Kristek who likes to remove the barriers between art and reality, deliberately got with his action in the way of passers-by to pull them out of their stereotype and to force them adopt an attitude. The artist dipped the balerina’s [[pointe shoe]]s into the paint and let her dance on a blank canvas.Putová 2013, p. 77. The pointe shoes also became part of the assemblage afterwards. Then he invited school pupils and passers-by to help to create the new assemblage, to paint and sew more mobile phones on to it. Art and life merged in the [[avant-garde]] sense. The assemblage travelled to an exhibition at the Barockschloß Riegersburg, today [[Schloss Ruegers]] (2007). The artist continued to travel with his mission to other states. With each happening interaction the assemblage changed its shape. In 2008, the happening series continued in the Neues Stadtmuseum, [[Landsberg am Lech]]. It was part of the retrospective exhibition of the works by Lubo Kristek titled ''Third Eye of Distant Communication''.{{cite web|first=Manuela|last=Rieger|url=http://www.augsburger-allgemeine.de/landsberg/Kunst-zum-Nachdenken-id3697011.html|title=Kunst zum Nachdenken|website=Augsburger Algemeine|publisher=|date=12 May 2008|access-date=16 August 2018|language=de}} {{Quote|In the happening a new character appeared, Temptation (played by the prima ballerina of the Brno National Theatre Jana Přibylová), who gives the spectators electronic devices from a pink sack and who suddenly turnes into the devil). In one of the last scenes, this character toys with a representation of human fate – a black figurine – which she throws to the ground as soon as she tires of her plaything. At the end of the happening, Kristek carried the pink sack full of electronic refuse to the altar of the Landsberg Church of the Holy Cross. In this way, he emphasised the sharp contrast between our ancestors´ legacy and what will remain after the current epoch.Putová 2018, [http://glyptotheque.com/index.php/meeting-point/requiem-for-mobile-telephones Chapter: Meeting place – Requiem for Mobile Telephones]}} The following happening took place in a Polish city of [[Sucha Beskidzka]] in 2010. According to Kristek, the relationship of contemporary society to the mobile telephone bears the traits of a [[cult]] or even a pathological dependency. Therefore he places this “modern god” on the altar (with the inscription Rest in Peace) and lets a giant triple-breasted angel to drill it through. The participants of the happening actively contribute to the act of [[sacrifice|sacrificing]] the mobile phones. {{Quote|The artist destroys the mobiles in the happenings. He disposes of them like refuse, but at the same time, he applies the ritual principle of sacrifice. The participants of the happening then “receive” the destroyed telephone (analogous with the torn up god) or even “consume” it via their reconnection in the creative process (analogous with the resurrection). The characters and spectators sew the mobiles on to the travelling assemblage, and they become co-creators of a work of art with a shape that changes from event to event. So through his message ''Requiem for Mobile Telephones'', Kristek achieves what he foretold in his picture ''The Moss Covered Telephone Call''. He experiments with the involvement of the public in events at he{Clarification}} interface between ritual and theatrical and creative art, with the use of random impulses during a collective creative process and with emphasis on the experiencing of the current moment. He attempts to restore lost communication and transform relations in an alienated “digital society”.}} ''Requiem for Mobile Telephones'' belongs to Kristek’s critical assemblages as well as ''Soundproof Aesthetic of Luxuriety'' (1976) that reveals the traps of consume approach and ''In the Prematurely Cloned Age of One Planet'' (2003) that questiones the ethics of current medical science. {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Sofar Sounds | logo = Sofar.png | foundation = {{start date and age|df=yes|2009}} | founder = Rocky Start, Rafe Offer, Dave Alexander | industry = Music | hq_location = [[London]], {{postcode|E|1}}
United Kingdom | area_served = Worldwide, over 350 cities[https://www.sofarsounds.com Sofar Sounds website] | homepage = https://www.sofarsounds.com }} '''Sofar Sounds''' (an acronym for ''Songs from a Room'') is a music events [[startup company]], based in [[Shoreditch]], founded in 2009. The company calls itself a global community where guests and artists come together to experience music in an intimate and respectful setting at a secret concert. {{toc limit|2}} ==History== {{Advert section|date=October 2018}} The events started in London in March 2009 by [https://rafe-offer.com/ Rafe Offer], Rocky Start and Dave J. Alexander who went to a [[Friendly Fires]] concert and became annoyed by people talking over the music, gazing into their [[Smartphone]]s{{cite news | title=Secret gigs place the next big thing right into your front room | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/apr/27/secret-gigs-pop-music-prince-batille | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | date=27 April 2014}} or hearing the clanging of beer bottles. As a consequence, they decided to put on their own gig in Alexander's [[North London]] flat and invited eight friends over to listen to him play five songs in his living room.{{cite news | title=How Sofar Sounds is redefining the live music scene around the globe | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/sofar-sounds-songs-from-a-room-live-music/ | publisher=[[CBS News]] | date=24 January 2017}} For the second gig in London, more people showed up because the word had spread. Soon after, Sofar expanded (mostly by word of mouth) to Paris, New York City, and other cities, arriving in Los Angeles in early 2011.{{cite web | title=How Did a Secret Concert Series With Mostly Unknown Bands Get So Popular? | url=http://www.laweekly.com/music/how-did-a-secret-concert-series-with-mostly-unknown-bands-get-so-popular-7339846 | publisher=[[LA Weekly]] | date=16 September 2016}} What started as a [[grassroots]] movement in London has eventually grown into a global community. In early 2017, Sofar Sounds claimed that they are putting on about 500 gigs per month in more than 300 cities worldwide.{{cite web | title=Fans Flock to Secret Home Concerts | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/fans-flock-to-secret-home-concerts-1486574385 | publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=8 February 2017}} ==Service== Typically, three artists perform at each Sofar gig with no "[[opening act|opener]]" and no "[[Headliner (performances)|headliner]]".[https://www.sofarsounds.com/faq "Frequently Asked Questions"] Sofar Sounds (Retrieved 31 May 2017.) Performers apply to be considered via a form on the website.[https://www.sofarsounds.com/about/artists "The best audience in the world"] Sofar Sounds (Retrieved 31 May 2017.) Musicians of all genres as well as [[spoken word]] [[poet]]s, [[comedian]]s and even dancers are welcome to apply.[https://www.sofarsounds.com/faq "Frequently Asked Questions"] Sofar Sounds (Retrieved 31 May 2017.) Local Sofar Sounds lead ambassadors / bookers and their review committees and music scouts curate the evenings.{{cite web | title=Are living room concerts the future? | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/38761302/are-living-room-concerts-the-future | publisher=[[BBC]] | date=27 January 2017}} The line-up for a concert is not disclosed until the event starts; the location (often a private [[living room]]http://pitchbook.com/news/search?query=sofar%20sounds with an average size of 70 people) is announced 24 hours before the show.{{cite web | title=The Modern Concert, Pt. 2: What Is Missing From The Artist-Brand Relationship in Live Music? | url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/cheriehu/2016/02/29/the-modern-concert-pt-2-what-is-missing-from-the-artist-brand-relationship-in-live-music/#c40714b254f8 | publisher=[[Forbes]] | date=29 February 2016}} Guests arrive on time for the first act and are encouraged to stay for the entire show. Events are normally [[BYOB]], and emphasis is placed on the crowd being respectful – switching off their phones and listening.{{cite web|title=East End Review|url=http://www.eastendreview.co.uk/2014/05/13/sofar-sounds-rafe-offar/|website=East End Review}} Sofar Sounds also claims that highlighting headline acts encourages people to turn up late and not respect the other performers, so that is why all artists are being treated equal.{{citation |title=Crack in the Road|url=http://www.crackintheroad.com/music/20639-feature-sofar-sounds|website=www.crackintheroad.com}} Artists are often filmed, with the edited video uploaded to the Sofar Sounds YouTube channel{{citation |title=Sofar Sounds YouTube channel|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/Sofarsounds|website=Youtube|accessdate=31 May 2017}} and shared on the website. ===Pricing and payments=== There are two types of Sofar cities: Full-time and [[Volunteering|volunteer]]/ambassador. The majority of Sofar cities are run by volunteers who put on one or two shows a month.[https://www.sofarsounds.com/faq "Frequently Asked Questions"] Sofar Sounds (Retrieved 31 May 2017.) In the majority of Sofar Sounds cities the audience does not pay beforehand but is encouraged to make a cash contribution at the show. In some cities in the US and UK, people can choose how much they pay for their [[Ticket (admission)|ticket]] prior to the show. The minimum amount is set by the local city team. In the rest of the Sofar cities, shows are ticketed. Tickets are $15 per person in the US,{{cite news | title=How Sofar Sounds is redefining the live music scene around the globe | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/sofar-sounds-songs-from-a-room-live-music/ | publisher=[[CBS News]] | date=24 January 2017}} £18 in the UK, and 200kr in Norway. Performing artists are either paid directly, or the A/V team on the night is paid to produce the video for the artists, depending on the [[Financial compensation|compensation]] agreed upon between artist and booker.[https://www.sofarsounds.com/faq "Frequently Asked Questions"] Sofar Sounds (Retrieved 31 May 2017.) ==Notable performers, partnerships, and investors== [[File:Bastille - War Child Sofar Show (23.02.15).jpg|thumb|Bastille performing at the Sofar Sounds x War Child charity event in London.]] In June 2015, Sofar Sounds partnered with [[Uber]] to host a series of secret gigs in London.{{cite web|title=Event Magazine|url=http://www.eventmagazine.co.uk/ubers-demand-ice-cream-activation-returns/brands/article/1357162|website=Event Magazine|publisher=Event Magazine|accessdate=31 May 2017}} In July 2016 it was announced that [[Virgin Group]]'s Sir [[Richard Branson]] would invest in Sofar Sounds.{{cite news | title=Richard Branson invests in secret gig start-up | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/07/14/richard-branson-invests-in-secret-gig-start-up/ | first=Rhiannon | last=Curry | work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | date=14 July 2016}} In March 2017 a partnership with [[Airbnb]] for their new Music Experiences format was announced,{{cite web | title=Airbnb Breaks into the Music Scene with Newly Launched Music Experiences | url=https://press.atairbnb.com/airbnb-breaks-into-the-music-scene-with-newly-launched-music-experiences/ | publisher=Airbnb Blog | date=8 March 2017}} which enables Airbnb customers in San Francisco to reserve seats at a Sofar event via the Trips platform.{{cite web | title=Sofar Sounds announces Airbnb Partnership | url=https://www.virgin.com/news/sofar-sounds-announces-airbnb-partnership | publisher=Virgin Blog | date=9 March 2017}} UK and Irish acts who have performed at Sofar shows include [[James Bay (singer)|James Bay]], [[Hozier (musician)|Hozier]], [[Emeli Sandé]], [[Will Young]],{{cite web|last1=Corner|first1=Lewis|title=Digital Spy|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a650397/premiere-will-young-performs-acoustic-version-of-love-revolution.html|website=Digital Spy|accessdate=31 May 2017}} [[Tom Odell]],[https://www.facebook.com/sofarsounds/photos/a.405124186096.176772.301642231096/10154161517186097/?type=3] Sofar Sounds Facebook page (Retrieved 31 May 2017.) [[Shura (English singer)|Shura]], [[Benjamin Clementine]], actor [[Robert Pattinson]],{{cite news|last1=Cowan|first1=Matt|title=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/video/2010/07/22/songs-from-a-room?videoId=123595601|accessdate=31 May 2017|work=Reuters Video|agency=Reuters|publisher=Reuters}} [[Wolf Alice]], [[Bastille (band)|Bastille]] and [[Lianne La Havas]]. Both Bastille{{cite web | title=Bastille Performs U.K. Gig in a Living Room for Sofar Sounds | url=http://observer.com/2015/02/exclusive-bastille-preforms-last-uk-gig-in-a-living-room-for-sofar-sounds | publisher=[[The Observer]] | date=24 February 2015}} and Lianne La Havas{{citation |title=War Child UK presents: Passport to Brits Week|url=http://www.liannelahavas.com/war-child-uk-presents-passport-to-brits-week/|publisher=Lianne La Havas' official website|date=20 January 2016 |accessdate=31 May 2017}} performed at special events in London that Sofar put on in collaboration with the [[Charitable organization|charity]] [[War Child (charity)|War Child]]. Bastille also took part in a special live-streamed Sofar Sounds #Voting show[https://www.facebook.com/sofarsounds/videos/10153517467666097/] Sofar Sounds Facebook page (Retrieved 31 May 2017.) that 'Give a Home' took place on 20 September 2017 and saw thousands of artists play intimate sets in living rooms in over 300 cities and 60 countries, in aid of the millions of refugees who were forced to flee their homes.{{cite web | title=‘Give a Home’: Massive global concert series will show solidarity with refugees | url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2017/06/give-a-home/ | publisher=[[Amnesty International]] | date=20 June 2017}} Confirmed artists included [[Ed Sheeran]], [[Moby]], [[Gregory Porter]], [[Daughter (band)|Daughter]], [[Jesse & Joy]], [[Hot Chip]], [[Ludovico Einaudi]], [[The National (band)|The National]], [[Mashrou' Leila]], and more.[https://www.sofarsounds.com/giveahome] Sofar Sounds Website (Retrieved 16 August 2017.) ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Official website}} [[Category:Entertainment companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Companies established in 2011]] [[Category:2011 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Companies based in the London Borough of Tower Hamlets]] [[Category:British companies established in 2011]] [[Category:Event management companies]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 2011]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2009]] [[Category:Culture in London]]
